PETITION.PRESENTERS: Carr, Sen Kim; Evans, Sen Chris
PETITION.TITLE: Telstra: Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators, and to the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that:
As members of the Australian community, considering:

PARA.TAB: the strategic important of Telstra in the national economy;
the high levels of foreign ownership in the rest of the telecommunications industry;
the growing importance of communications services to the lives of all Australians;
the threat that privatisation poses to the universal availability of both present and future communications services;

PETITION.PARA: We believe that it is in the national interest for Telstra to be kept in full public ownership.

We therefore call on the Federal Government to abandon its proposal to privatise Telstra, the nation's chief telecommunications provider, and to explore alternative means of funding its environmental policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Carr (from 410 citizens)and Senator Chris Evans (from 600 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that "The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC".
2. The Senate votes to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
3. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Ramsar Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia in Geelong requests that the Senate examine the proposal to set aside land currently protected under the Ramsar Treaty in order to provide for a chemical storage facility at Pt Lillias. Further, we request the Senate to examine whether the proposal to set aside an area alternate to the one now nominated by the Ramsar Treaty is in accordance with the requirement of that Treaty.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
One of the key challenges this nation faces is to preserve its natural environmental capital for the benefit of our children and grandchildren.

Australians overwhelmingly believe that environment protection and economic growth are equally important. The challenge for Australia is to sustain the rapid advances in living standards that have been achieved in the 20th century in a way that protects the life support systems which are increasingly threatened.

This is a challenge that all governments around the world must accept. Every society has a responsibility to future generations to leave an environment which is at least as healthy and productive as the one they inherit.

The purpose of this Bill is to tackle these challenges head-on by establishing a one billion dollar Natural Heritage Trust of Australia. This Trust is the major mechanism for the implementation of the Coalition Government's policies for the protection and rehabilitation of Australia's natural environment.

The initiatives to be funded from the Trust are aimed at reversing the decline in our natural capital. They will contribute to the conservation, repair and enhancement of Australia's unique environment into the 21st Century.
This is the first time in the nation's history a Commonwealth Government has established a Trust for such a purpose.
The Trust will provide funding certainty for important natural heritage programs of this Coalition Government for the next five years.

Overall the government will spend an additional $1.15 billion over the next 5 years, on a comprehensive package of measures aimed at tackling the environmental and sustainable agriculture challenges facing Australia. The Trust is the centrepiece upon which this extensive package of measures depends.

Australia must seize the opportunity to play a leading role as a clean, green nation. This objective is not only of environmental importance but will produce major economic benefits and job opportunities for regional Australia and the nation.

This Bill is a key plank in meeting this challenge. It is part of the largest and most comprehensive commitment to action on the environment and to restoring our natural capital by any national government in Australia's history.
Let me put the initiative in its proper context.

We have inherited an environment in serious difficulties. Little of our natural environment has escaped modification, and what remains is under increasing pressure. It is estimated that over 5 million hectares of native vegetation were cleared during the decade between 1983 and 1993. Once widespread species are declining. Some 20 mammal, 20 bird and 68 plant species are already presumed extinct. Many of our wetlands have disappeared and the water quality and flows of our key rivers are dramatically reduced. The productive capacity of our land has been damaged through erosion, salinity, loss of structure or acidification.

These problems have a direct impact on people in our community who, quite rightly, expect quality water to drink and clean air to breathe. They do not want to see precious soils blown away in the wind, blue-green algae spoiling our rivers and streams, or our unique flora and fauna at risk.

The establishment of this Trust enables Australia to take a dramatic leap forward in the sustainable management of our natural capital. It provides the opportunity to take a new approach to environmental protection and natural resource management, and to design and integrate programs to ensure strong multiple outcomes.
I would now like to explain the Trust in more detail.

This Bill will establish the Trust and provide for it to be known as the "Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Reserve". The initial capital of one billion dollars to be invested in the Trust will come from the proceeds of the partial sale of Telstra.

In effect, the transfer of funds from the partial sale of Telstra into the Natural Heritage Trust represents a transfer from investment in a telecommunications company to an investment in natural capital. Maintaining and restoring this natural capital is an investment in the well-being of future generations of Australians.
For too long Australia has taken its extraordinary endowment of natural resources for granted.

We have failed to take into account the depletion and degradation of our natural capital and we have failed to make the investments in management and works necessary to arrest and reverse the depreciation of our natural resources.
It is not by chance that the Government's natural heritage package is focused around the big issues of our time—land and water degradation; coastal protection and the conservation of biodiversity.

Each has a compelling claim on our resources, but if we were to simply deal with each separately the results would be modest. We would be perpetuating the mistakes of the past if we were to attempt to deal with each of these issues in isolation from each other.

The Trust, and the range of initiatives it will support, is based on a recognition that an integrated approach is needed right across the spectrum of problems we face. The initiatives to be funded from the Trust have therefore been strategically developed around five interdependent environmental packages:
. Vegetation;
. Rivers;
. Biodiversity;
. Landcare; and
. Coasts and Oceans.

Within these five packages, seven hundred million dollars of the money invested in the Trust from the partial sale of Telstra will be devoted entirely to five capital projects aimed at maintaining, protecting and replenishing Australia's natural environmental capital. These projects, which will be conducted over a five year period, are:
. the National Vegetation Initiative;
. the Murray-Darling 2001 Project;
. the National Reserve System;
. the National Land and Water Resources Audit; and
. the Coasts and Clean Seas Initiative.

These five capital initiatives will be complemented by a comprehensive range of other environmental and sustainable agriculture initiatives announced as part of this Government's Saving our Natural Heritage and Reviving the Heartland Packages.

The Bill provides for funds in the Trust to be invested and for all income from such investments to be returned to the Trust. The Bill also enables funds from a number of other sources to be paid into the Trust. This will include, for example, budget appropriations and gifts or bequests.

All interest earned from the Trust and other non-Telstra monies invested in the Trust will be able to be spent on other environmental and sustainable agriculture projects, such as rivercare, endangered species, landcare, and addressing the management and control of weeds and feral animals.

At the end of the five years, three hundred million dollars will remain in the Trust as a capital base. This money will be held in perpetuity, to continue to enhance the quality of our environment for all Australians.

The Trust will be the source of funds for a number of the Government's environment and sustainable land and water programs, which are managed within both the Environment and Primary Industries and Energy Portfolios.

To facilitate the management of the Trust as a partnership between the two Portfolios, the Bill establishes a Natural Heritage Board, comprising the Minister for the Environment and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Board will provide a formal mechanism for liaison and co-operation between the two Portfolios on all matters relating to the Trust, to ensure a comprehensive integration of the Government's environment and sustainable agriculture programs.

This reflects an historic recognition that protection of the environment for future generations can only be achieved through an integrated response to our environmental and sustainable agriculture problems.
I would now like to describe the five environmental packages in more detail.
Probably the most compelling environmental challenge for Australia is turning around the relentless long term decline in the quality and extent of our native vegetation.
It is estimated we have cleared 20 billion trees over the past 200 years and, with mechanisation, the pace of clearing increased dramatically over the past 30 to 40 years.

Native vegetation communities, including grasslands, shrublands, woodlands and forests, represent priceless natural capital—underpinning biodiversity values, catchment hydrology, water quality, and of course the unique character of Australian landscapes.
There is also a developing consciousness of the importance of remnant vegetation to sustainable agriculture.

The Government's National Vegetation Initiative will ameliorate the land and water degradation and the loss of biodiversity associated with the reduction in native vegetation cover since European settlement. The Initiative will support a range of revegetation activities and develop incentives for the protection and sustainable management of remnant native vegetation.
Our objective is to ensure that, for the first time since European settlement, the rate of revegetation in Australia exceeds the rate of vegetation clearance.
Funding will also be provided for a related initiative, the Farm Forestry Program. This will further promote and encourage the establishment of commercial farm forestry activities in regional areas.

The National Vegetation Initiative provides for the establishment of an expert advisory Council for Sustainable Vegetation Management which will have the task of providing advice to the Government on the Initiative.

In addition to the direct benefits of such environmental restoration, this Initiative will also provide an important addition to carbon sinks for greenhouse gases in Australia, contributing to the global effort to address climate change.
The National Vegetation Initiative represents an historic opportunity to put in place the first integrated national program for protecting and enhancing Australia's native vegetation.
The restoration of our waterways must become a key environmental priority for all Australians.

It is an integral part of ecological processes on which all life depends and supports a wide range of uses—industry, irrigation, urban and rural development, recreation and landscape amenity—all of which are fundamental to our quality of life.

Yet we have not treated our scarce water resources wisely. In the Murray Darling Basin, for example, if all the water allocations were implemented, 90 percent of the average natural flow would be diverted. That system now experiences drought level flows three years out of every four, compared to one in twenty years under natural circumstances.
This Government recognises that there is a need to strike a better balance between consumptive and environmental demands for water.

While current activities being carried out through joint Government and community programs are meeting with some success, the Government believes that substantially more resources need to be allocated to improve the sustainable management and conservation of rivers and other waterways.
The Murray-Darling 2001 Project is an integral component of this Government's comprehensive package of water reform measures, designed to clean up our waterways and coastline.

It will complement other new programs such as the National Rivercare Initiative, which will focus on ensuring sustainable management, rehabilitation and conservation of waterways outside the Murray-Darling Basin.
The Government is also committed to enhancing the National Wetlands Program, to encourage the conservation of Australia's precious wetlands.

These initiatives will result in improved water quality, increased environmental flows, retention of essential habitat and improved waste management practices to enable reuse of waste water, stormwater and sewerage.
Australia's plants and animals have evolved in isolation from the rest of the world for over 40 million years.
As a result, we have been endowed with a splendid variety of life forms that are found nowhere else on earth. We have a great responsibility to care for and protect this unique natural heritage.
The National Reserve System initiative will develop, in conjunction with the States and Territories, a comprehensive, adequate and representative National Reserve System.

The Reserve System will incorporate prime examples of Australia's biodiversity and significant natural values. It will ensure that a representative wide range of ecosystems are protected. This will include, for example, wilderness, wild rivers, wetlands, salt marshes and grasslands. The Reserve System will also reflect the need to protect and promote the recovery of species and ecological communities that are endangered or vulnerable.
The National Reserve System will complement off-reserve conservation activities which will include other elements of this investment package, such as the National Vegetation Initiative.

The Government also recognises the importance of providing specific resources towards ensuring the recovery of endangered species and ecological communities and will therefore provide additional funding for the Endangered Species Program.
Despite the success and rapid growth in landcare and the commitment by the Australian community to the landcare ethos, this Government believes that more urgent action is needed.

It is now well accepted that we must move away from an awareness raising phase to on-ground action. Australia has a strong public interest in supporting farmers to take practical action. In return, the community must see changes in farming practices to ensure its investment has lasting environmental benefits.

This Government is committed to significantly increased funding for the National Landcare Program. The additional funding will provide much needed support for implementation of plans, based on a catchment and regional approach. Substantially increased support will also be provided for the development of community initiated and managed projects on public and private land.

In addition, funding for property management planning will be provided under the Rural Adjustment Scheme in recognition that farmers need to integrate the management of their natural resources with farm business planning.
These measures will be reinforced by the provision of income tax rebate and credits for qualifying landcare works on private land.

Recognising the importance of dealing with weeds and feral pests as part of the overall natural resource management task, additional funding will also be provided for a National Feral Animal Control Strategy and for the implementation of the National Weeds Strategy.
In order to ensure that our limited resources are used wisely and are focused on strategic priorities, the Trust will fund a National Land and Water Resources Audit.
This audit will provide the first ever comprehensive appraisal of the extent of land and water degradation in Australia and its environmental, social and economic costs to the nation.
It will incorporate an assessment of water resources to determine the extent of the resource as a step towards achieving a balance in water supply and use.
Critically, it will provide essential information on the state of Australia's natural resources to underpin better decision making for natural resource management in the future.

Australia's coastal zone supports about 86% of our population and much of our commercial and industrial activity. In addition, our Exclusive Economic Zone represents some 11 million square kilometres of marine waters and their resources.
Clearly, the ecologically sustainable management of our coasts and oceans is integral to our way of life and economic prosperity.

The Trust will therefore fund a Coasts and Clean Seas Initiative, to tackle coastal pollution hot spots and threats to Australia's coastal water quality and marine biodiversity. We will focus on previously neglected areas of policy, such as ocean outfalls, stormwater pollution, and marine research.
In consultation with all major stakeholders we will develop a comprehensive and integrated Oceans Policy for Australia.

We will assist State and Territory Governments to reduce the environmental impacts of ocean outfalls and to address the threat of stormwater pollution to our urban beaches and environmentally sensitive coastal areas.
Funds will be also be provided to enable local groups and individuals to become directly involved in coastal restoration works.
For the benefit of future generations of Australians, communities, industry and government each have an obligation to play a part in protecting the environment.

A distinguishing feature of the Coalition's approach to the environment is that we have considerable faith in the Australian people to work positively and cooperatively to confront this national challenge.

The Government is therefore committed to developing a cooperative approach to the implementation of the programs I have outlined, to tap into the enormous enthusiasm which exists throughout the Australian community for the restoration and protection of our unique environment.

We are committed to achieving a greater level of cooperation between the three spheres of government to deliver resources to local communities and landholders. Too many reports currently sit on shelves and too many programs are too inflexible for local needs.
We will ensure that communities and landholders have an important role in priority setting processes, and that the delivery mechanisms will be as streamlined as possible.

We will work with the community, farmers, local and state and territory Governments, volunteer organisations, industry, environmental groups and the scientific community in a cooperative and coordinated manner.

In particular, the Government recognises that if we are to succeed in better managing our environment and the natural resources in our vast rural heartland, then we require the full support of farm families and the rural communities in which they live.
In designing and delivering these major initiatives, the Government will develop integrated approaches to minimise the number of separate programs and consequent administrative burden.

The establishment of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia and the integrated package of initiatives supported by the funds from this Trust represents the most significant environmental investment ever put forward by an Australian government.
The investment proposed in this Bill, which will be made possible by the partial privatisation of Telstra, will reverse the long-term depreciation of our natural capital.

The establishment of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia, and the major initiatives to be funded through the Trust, demonstrates this Government's commitment to ensuring a cleaner, greener and more sustainably productive Australia.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering schedule 1 and dealing with government amendments Nos 1 to 7. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the first schedule of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. The objectives contained in the schedule provide an opportunity to make a general comment on the principles underlying this bill, as well as to comment on the particular amendments which we will be moving during discussion of this schedule in the debate. The outline given to us yesterday by Senator Campbell on behalf of the government in respect of this section were extraordinarily superficial, for what are the objectives of an act? The objectives of any act are an important indication of the philosophy and the major themes that are identified in the act.

SPEECH.PARA: In dealing with a matter of this significance, I find the superficiality of the approach of the government extraordinary in respect of the changes that they are advancing, as well as justifying the various objectives that are outlined. Frankly, that does not come as a surprise, given this government's attitude to industrial relations, which is extraordinarily superficial generally. Their approach to industrial relations is marked by grandiose claims about the requirement for industrial relations reform in order to regenerate the economy.

Some two or three months ago, the grandiose claims included reduction in unemployment. They have dropped that line in recent months. They are now taking a much lower profile as a justification for reducing unemployment. I am sure they are doing this because they have looked at both the official estimate in the budget and the official projection for unemployment—which they refuse to release—which, I have no doubt, will show that unemployment is likely to remain high for some years and that the contribution that industrial relations reform makes in that area, at best, will be very minimal.

We have the superficiality of the government in dealing with the objectives clause. The grandiose claims they make—the jargon they use about the requirement for flexibility, releasing the chains and shackles of the industrial relations system, the surge in productivity, and the absolute guarantee that the Prime Minister gave that no worker would be worse off—are the sorts of superficiality that we contend are manifestly incorrect and untrue.

When looking at the objectives of the act, I want to comment on the agreed statement of the Australian Democrats and the Liberal government. It is a fairly extraordinary document. In my six years in the Senate, I cannot recall a time when the government moved amendments on behalf of the Australian Democrats, as they are in this objectives section and, indeed, will be doing right throughout the bill. There may be some strategic advantage for the government in moving the amendments first, but I am surprised that the Australian Democrats would accept and adopt that position.

PARA.BREAK: The document itself, containing some 100 pages including 171 amendments and, obvi ously, some amendments to the objectives in schedule 1, is almost like a peace treaty in its breadth. It is a fairly extraordinary position that the Australian Democrats and the Liberal government have adopted in terms of the process. The unusual approach that has been adopted by the Democrats and the Liberals does not end with the objectives. We find that this agreement, as it relates to objectives and to all other schedules in the bill, is essentially an outcome that we could foresee, but it is a regrettable outcome because it confirms our worst fears about this industrial relations bill.

SPEECH.PARA: What has emerged will bring about some improvement of the government's initial proposal. I draw the attention of government senators, particularly backbenchers, to the policy that they took to the election. Look at what Minister Reith laid down when he first released the bill some two months ago and look at what has now been agreed between the Australian Democrats and the Liberal Party as a consequence of their deal which is reflected in this document.

From our perspective, the bill which was released two months ago with the objectives contained therein, was an atrocious and unfair bill. I and my colleagues spoke extensively in the second reading debate on behalf of the Labor opposition about the various aspects of the unfairness and the atrocious position which this government and to some extent the Australian Democrats have now adopted as a consequence of this document. We will deal with that in considerable detail in this committee stage.

What they have done by this agreed statement of position is turn an atrocious and unfair bill that we fundamentally oppose—and will still continue to fundamentally oppose, albeit we will be moving a significant number of amendments—into an unsatisfactory bill that still contains many areas that are unfair and unsatisfactory. This is certainly highlighted in the objectives of the bill.

As far as we are concerned, this deal—this agreed statement of position—between the government and the Australian Democrats will continue to leave Australian workers at a significant disadvantage. There will be less security for Australian workers concerning their wages and conditions. Australian workers will be less secure about their jobs. They will be exposed to an increase in individual contracts and their right to collectively bargain will be significantly undermined. As I said earlier, now not even the strongest advocates of this bill are saying that it will do anything to reduce unemployment by the end of this century.

Again, with respect to this agreed statement of position and deal between the Democrats and the Liberal government, I can recall some two months ago when we foreshadowed extensive amendments—some 300‐odd amendments that we are pursuing in the committee stage—the shock and horror that the minister, Mr Reith, expressed about how dare we foreshadow such an extensive range of amendments. How dare we do that. They had a policy and they were determined to pursue it. They had legislation. Why should we as a Labor opposition put forward such a range of amendments.

Yet here today, and for the first time publicly released on Sunday—we had the opportunity to read them in some detail yesterday—we have 171 amendments from the government and the Australian Democrats vis‐a‐vis their deal. Contrast that with the statements from Minister Reith some months ago complaining about any foreshadowed range of amendments that Labor put forward. Yet we are given one day's notice of what was worked out between the Liberals and the Australian Democrats.

I turn to the objectives of the bill. We make it very clear in paragraph (a) that the act is to provide a framework for cooperative industrial relations, not just cooperative workplace relations, as is provided for in the government's objectives, and supported by the Australian Democrats. It is important to understand that industrial relations is not just about workplace relations and workplace negotiation. That is an important part of industrial relations. The objectives of the government purely focus on cooperative workplace relations when there should be an industry wide focus in addition to a workplace focus. This should be contained in the objectives of the bill, and it is not.

BREAK.PARA: We also add a requirement in paragraph (a) to encourage the pursuit of better pay. How many times has the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, reminded us that industrial relations and their approach is all about better pay for every Australian worker? Why isn't it in this bill as part of the objectives? Better pay for everyone is the nirvana that the Prime Minister promised. Where is that in the objectives of this bill? All their rhetoric has been focused on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, we are very happy to support a change to the objectives adopting the Prime Minister's objective. We cannot understand why you do not have as an objective promoting better pay for all Australian workers, as you promised in the lead-up to the election and as you have committed yourselves to since the election, and as all your rhetoric surrounding this bill proclaims.

BREAK.PARA: In terms of a fair labour market, there is a change here. The government has as one of its amendments a reference to a fair labour market. We are pleased that they picked up this in the new amendments that have been circulated. We are pleased because this is one of our amendments. We are pleased to see that the Australian Democrats and the government have decided to adopt wording to the effect that there is a fair labour market.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are fair.
—Senator, we would still like you to pick up the objective of better pay for all because that is what you have been proclaiming.

BREAK.PARA: We heard significant comment today about the Prime Minister expressing his concern about better pay for executives. I wonder what his position will be in the sense of this bill when it is passed.

In paragraph (b) we insert a guarantee that no employee will be worse off as a result of the implementation of this bill. In particular, no trainee or apprentice will receive less take home pay than the relative entitlement under the applicable award. Again, the Prime Minister has made it very clear time and again, both before the election and after, that no-one will be worse off. This is vitally important, particularly in respect of trainees and apprentices, as we reflect in our change to the objectives in paragraph (b). These people are amongst the most vulnerable in the work force and this should be specifically enshrined in this bill. The Prime Minister proclaims this and Mr Reith proclaims it. What is wrong with ensuring in the objectives that no-one can be worse off as a result? I will be making some further remarks about the objectives later in this section of the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens totally oppose the philosophical directions that are so apparent in the principal object clause of this Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. It is important to clearly state that the principal object clause is not just a superfluous item of rhetorical flare. Potentially, it can be used in any legal interpretation of clauses in the bill which are deemed to be unclear in intent or ambiguous. Debate on this clause is therefore very important. For example, the government's principal object clause states that the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia can be achieved through achieving such things as `international competitiveness' and `a flexible labour market'.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the latter day equivalent of the trickle‐down effect and it is, in effect, a code for the reduction of pay and conditions for the vast majority of workers, particularly unskilled or low skilled workers. These workers will be forced to compete with the low wages and conditions that are endemic in developing countries. The alternative is unemployment as Australian corporations chase those low wages in developing nations. It is all part of the international race to the bottom that is a part of the new internationalism that was started by the previous Labor government with the strong support of the coalition.

In relation to these Democrat‐government amendments Nos. 1 to 7, I would have to say that the wording is better than the previous wording; therefore I will vote for the improved wording. However, the Greens have amendments to the principal object clause. I notice, as Senator Sherry has said, that the ALP also have amendments to the bill. There are some areas of deep concern and there are some common areas of concern that exist also within the ALP amendments.

As I say, I believe that a lot of the issues revolve around this belief that was started with the ALP in relation to the push for international competitiveness in order to try to make up for the deficiencies in what was meant to come as the huge benefits of free international trade. The issue is whether or not the worker is primarily responsible for Australia's current economic situation. I believe the principal object of this bill says that. It actually points to the average worker and says, `It's your fault. If only you would work harder. If only you would be prepared to work odd hours for the same rates or didn't require penalty rates or didn't have to have penalties for working when you would prefer to be with your family. If only you would be prepared to do that, we could all be better off.' I think that is erroneous and I think it is not admitting what the real economic issues are in Australia.

I was thinking this morning of a way to describe the whole situation in this bill, and this is probably a good time to put it. What we had with the original bill, as is embodied by this principle, is the cutting off of legs in relation to bargaining power. It would be pretty awkward for many people to survive without a leg. With the amendments, we only have the feet cut off. So we have people who cannot walk without assistance apart from hopping, one would assume. But we are going to put into the bill that people are quite free to walk—there are no restrictions against walking. Isn't that terrific! You haven't got a foot but there are no restrictions. There is nothing in this bill that says you are not able to walk. But, if you are going to walk, you will need assistance—and that is what I think you need with collective bargaining.

That is the parable that I am putting. These amendments are better—you are only cutting off a foot; you are not cutting off the leg—but you are taking away the crutches. You are taking away the assistance that people will need to be able to walk and bargain with any kind of equality within the system. Whilst I will agree to the amendments Nos. 1 to 7 in relation to these principal objects, I will speak later on my own amendments and what I think would be more appropriate in the principal objects of the bill. I certainly recognise that the ALP's amendments to the principal objects have better elements than the current general gist of the Democrat‐government amendments. However, they still embody what I think was the beginning of the farce and the beginning of the con of workers in Australia—that if only they could be internationally competitive, if only they could work faster and harder for less wages and more flexibly, they would stop the damage that they are doing to the Australian economy. It is time for honesty.

I believe that I can read the numbers. I can see that whatever we do, amendments Nos. 1 to 7 will be carried. But that will not stop me, and I am sure that it will not stop the ALP from moving their amendments and from putting what I believe should be a model for what the principal object should be, if we are looking for a 1996 bill and not a 1986 bill in relation to industrial relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to some general comments with respect to the objects, firstly, I would like to go back to the Democrat‐government agreement and the comment that they make in the summary of their agreed position:

SPEECH.PARA: The objects will continue to reinforce the primary emphasis and directions of the reforms.
I actually do think that the objects, as they stand in this agreed position, do continue to do that.

On considering the commentary with respect to the agreement, and in the context of how well the objects continue to reflect that, I had a look at the description of the overall bill from the Senate Economics References Committee. I will take us back to just one comment in that. At 1.2 in chapter 1 of the overview, the majority of the committee stated:

The Workplace Relations Bill represents a significant remodelling of Australia's industrial relations system. The Bill proposes the reshaping of bargain ing arrangements, the confinement of awards to that of a minimum safety net, and a reduction in the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and registered organisations.

This agreement still does all of that, quite clearly. In my remarks, at this stage, I will concentrate on the confinement of awards, because I do not believe it is just a confinement. These changes, despite the agreed amendments, will destroy the award system that we have had in Australia for near a century. We are not just talking about some remodelling to fit the current economic circumstances; we are talking about changes which destroy Australia's award system.

I applaud the Democrats and their agreement for bringing the government to the position of including fairness, because as we travelled around Australia, that was one of the very clear and obvious things that the government continued to try and ignore in its ideological bent with this bill. I applaud that we now have reference to fairness in the objects but, as Senator Sherry has pointed out, the objects should reflect other things, such as the government's election commitment—their commitment to better pay, their commitment that workers will be no worse off—as I think Senator Murray also referred to in his report.

At this stage, I would like to focus on and ask the government: whilst we understand the need to emphasise workplace relations and accept that, why now do the objects not more adequately deal with the award system other than as a minimum safety net? This is perhaps an obvious question, because I think that the changes which occur in the bill highlight the point that I made earlier. The objects no longer reflect a description of awards as other than the minimum safety net, because there is no intention that they should.

There is no intention that we should have a vibrant award system to protect workers. There is no intention that we should be able to describe awards, as the act currently does, or that the system should provide the means for establishing and maintaining an effective framework of protecting wages and conditions of employment through awards—not just minimum safety net awards.

BREAK.PARA: Just to highlight where I think the object should be improved, references regarding awards providing relevant, secure and consistent wages and conditions should be maintained in the bill. They have been removed later in the bill. I think it is quite clear to us why that is the case, because we will only have awards as minimum safety nets. I am not sure it is clear how changing the objects and changing the thrust of the bill affects awards to some of the parties.

In this sense, unfortunately, despite all of the good intentions that the Democrats have made in previous policy positions and in their report after the inquiry, I think that they have been duped on this question. I do not think that they quite understand that the overall thrust of our industrial relations system has been destroyed by this change to awards. It may only seem like a small area, but it basically destroys the unique system that Australia has had in place for near on a century.

The other area I would highlight where changes need to be made with respect to the objects, and following from these comments that I have just made, is that arbitration should occur where necessary with respect to dispute resolution—not just where appropriate. That has been the nature of our award system. They have been vibrant living things dealing with industrial disputation and promoting industrial harmony. I commend the Greens on their amendment in that respect.

The whole thrust of awards promoting industrial harmony and dealing with industrial disputation has been destroyed. Now, at the very stretch, the government has agreed that we will have arbitration, where appropriate. When is `where appropriate'? If you look a bit further on in the bill `where appropriate' is the 20 allowable matters and `in exceptional circumstances'. At this stage, the government is going to have to be quite clear about what it means by `exceptional' as well.

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission is going to be kept very busy in times to come. Ten per cent budget cuts are not going to help them much as they try and discern what constitutes 20 allowable matters, what constitutes exceptional circumstances? Any thought that work will be taken away from the commission is a bit simplistic. Awards will not be simplified that quickly. There will be a lot of disputation.

Let me go back to the fundamental issue of this attack on the award system which, again, as I said earlier, I think unfortunately the Democrats have been duped into accepting. As I said, it ends an era in Australia. It ends an era in which, in recent times—for about the last decade—we have been able to introduce bargaining flexibility in an environment of security, fairness and trust. This will change.

Just to remove one of the illusions which were reflected in the objects and the general commentary to date on the bill, opposition to Australia's unique industrial relations system is not new. The thrust of this bill and Howard's industrial relations agenda is not new. Some people have this perception that it is a new thing to deal with our current economic circumstances and international markets, et cetera. It does not simply reflect the need for reform to deal with our economic circumstances.

It reflects the ascendancy of the New Right in the Liberal Party over the last several years and their ideological agenda. That is quite clear. This has been obvious by the approach to the bill to date in ignoring substantive concerns, concerns which the Democrats picked up in several areas throughout the inquiry and in their report, but concerns which seem to have been lost in some areas particularly with respect to awards in recent times. On my perception, the Democrats have been duped, by Reith, away from their position as they reported it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Chairman: this is a small point, but I do think that Senator Collins should refer to both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations as Mr Howard and Mr Reith.
—I am sorry, I missed it. But it is good advice.

—I will certainly accept that advice. I should go back to the point. I think the Democrats have been duped by the minister, Mr Reith, away from their position as they reported in the report—the position which said, for instance, that section 89A, with respect to awards, must more accurately reflect the government's pre-election commitments, that the removal of award conditions after 18 months would be a breach by Mr Howard of a pre-election commitment, page 333.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to take us back to that pre-election commitment. The Democrats accept that removing award conditions after 18 months just because they did not fit into the 18 allowable matters was a breach of this commitment. The commitment that the Democrats have referred to in their report was that no worker in Australia, under Mr Howard's industrial relations policy, can have his or her award conditions taken away. I'm sorry, but they will be taken away.

I am particularly disappointed that award conditions will be taken away in one area which is perhaps an area where the object should more effectively deal with situations with respect to awards which are going to be minimised; that is, occupational health and safety. Occupational health and safety reflects very well what I want to highlight about awards. What it reflects is that awards have historically been those vibrant things that deal with industrial disputation for the general public interest.

I suspect that Mr Reith, the minister, said to the Democrats, `Don't worry about occupational health and safety because there is legislation that deals with occupational health and safety.' But what exists in many awards are provisions specific to particular industries. We heard about provisions for shearers, for instance, which are not clearly provided for in industrial legislation. I know of retail award provisions dealing with health and safety issues which are not adequately provided for in industrial legislation. Let us not delude ourselves. Employers are not going to bargain and agree to those sorts of provisions no matter how many small little prods the government thinks they might be given. They will not bargain unless they have to.

Let me make it quite clear where I think the Democrats have been duped in terms of the objects. The object with respect to awards in the agreed position refers to awards solely as a safety net. The Democrats' confusion on this issue is obvious by their approach to awards in the agreed position. They want to protect paid rates awards but they allow award minimisation.

In fact, strangely there will be a reward for people not on paid rates awards since compulsory arbitration is being removed from several areas and there will be a reward for people who undertake industrial action which causes severe harm publicly. In those circumstances, you will have access to arbitration but bad luck to anybody else. Let us cause more industrial disputation because that is the way we will actually get the commission to do something. It does not make much sense.

It is obvious from reading the report that the Democrats have tried in several areas to improve the bill as much as they thought they could. But not allowing it to include arbitration means that all industrial disputes won't be able to be dealt with by the commission. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the objects of the bill. It is very important, as Senator Margetts pointed out, that they be taken into account when legal interpretation has to be made. It is important that the objects are consistent with the detail of the legislation and that the legislation is consistent with the objects. There has been some improvement as a result of the coalition-Democrat deal, but I think the most significant thing is that, even despite the coalition-Democrat deal, the legislation is still consistently bad. The objects that the Democrats have agreed to are inadequate and flawed. They have accepted the limitation of `workplace relations' in the objects as opposed, for example, to Labor's `industrial relations'. That is very significant.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the worst example of the Democrat-coalition deal is that it fails to take in the fundamental object proposed by the Labor Party of better pay. I urge the Democrats to reconsider their position on that. In the same way, Labor proposes a new object (b) and I believe that should be supported. There is no excuse for not supporting guaranteeing that no employee will be worse off as a result of implementation of this act and, in particular, that no trainee or apprentice will receive less take-home pay than the relevant entitlement under the applicable award.

It is worth while comparing the various objects that have been proposed by the various parties. As I have just said, a critical commencement point is the comparison between the Labor proposal of providing a cooperative industrial relations object and the limitation that is being proposed by the government and accepted by the Democrats where they narrow that cooperative arrangement to the workplace alone.

Why won't the coalition government adopt industrial relations legislation which sets the scene for cooperative industrial relations by adopting objects which reflect the values of cooperation, fairness and collective bargaining? By continuing to limit its attentions to workplace relations, the government is denying the need for industry activity or sectoral activity. This is the narrowness of the government's focus.

Because of its narrow focus, it ignores the importance of establishing industry‐wide solutions, for example, industry‐wide training schemes. There is no better example than in the metals industry where a complete change of culture was established, giving people career paths for the first time. It is all very well for professional people to have a career path, but we want, if industry is to be effective, for there to be industry solutions. An industry‐wide approach makes it more difficult for the individual bad employer, for one exists in every industry, to become dominant. Once there is industry‐wide pressure, and if the system and the objects of a system are based on industry‐wide activity, then that acts as pressure on the employer who would do the wrong thing.

In the same way, it allows for development of the human capital of the industry by concentrating on industry needs. It raises understanding when you look at world best practice ideas and adds pressure for industries themselves to look outward, and that has been shown by the successful examples where industries that were on their knees have been pulled up. You have it in the steel industry, the clothing industry, the shipbuilding industry and a number of other industries where that catalyst of having an industry approach has been used to good effect.

This government has done the opposite. Yesterday at 6 o'clock in South Australia the last group of workers at Griffin Press, who are going to be given the sack as a result of this capricious government's decision on the book bounty, were being given notice. That is an example of this government's resentment about a sector—in this case a sector of the printing industry. In this case, they are taking away from an industry that had planned its future the ability to gain markets or to keep those markets it has in Japan and other places. At the moment, there are several hundred people in that book industry who are being hurt. So I appreciate that this government does not understand the need of sector or industry approaches.

The government focuses on the workplace rather than on industrial relations in the objects of the bill. It reflects your desire to segment the labour force. You assume that there is strength in numbers, so you are setting up a system in which employers will be able to pick off individual workers and fragment workplaces one by one. This shows, I believe, that all your rhetoric about better work, increased productivity, best practice and excellence in management is false, because this government is trying to adopt the United States model of industrial relations, and it has a history of wanting to do this.

In the early 1980s, Senator Campbell, your colleague Ian Viner, when minister for industrial relations in the Fraser government, announced that he would introduce United States style legislation based on workplace activity—exactly the model that we face today. He announced it to the United States Chamber of Commerce in Australia. He told the big companies that were reflected there that he was going to deliver them the American industrial relations model in this country. But of course Malcolm Fraser—or the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser; I am not sure what he is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sport. He's a sport.

—He was not only a sport but he was an intelligent leader and he quickly moved the Hon. Ian Viner out of industrial relations because he was facing an election in 1983. It did not save the Hon. Malcolm Fraser. He was defeated. You will remember that he was defeated at a time when, in industrial relations, we had anarchy as the order of the day. It was quite well known that the anarchy that existed as part of government policy under the Fraser government was something that had to be addressed very quickly by the incoming Labor government in 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: What you had was instability and insecurity in industrial relations at the end of the Fraser government period. What is happening now is that that instability and insecurity is going to be transferred on to ordinary wage plugs—on to the wage and salary earners in this country. They will have instability and insecurity when the objects of this bill are translated into practice under the legislation.

What the Hawke government did was pull industry leaders together. It concentrated on industrial relations in line with the object that we put forward today. It made industrial relations the centre of a new culture of modernisation. Health and safety and work practices were approached on a cooperative basis. People have forgotten in Australia that it was in 1983, and shortly after, that, for the first time, we did have a workplace emphasis. We encouraged every person to look at their workplace and we, through industry programs, were able to encourage the improvement of health and safety.

So we are not against the emphasis on health and safety or on approaching the workplace itself. But we know that to be successful if you are fair dinkum about getting improvement you have to do it on a cooperative basis. You have to mobilise the resources of an industry. You have to use the good experiences of one place to encourage change in others. They are the sorts of things that Labor did in office. That is just the opposite to the proposals in these objects which do not accept industrial relations based objects but want to go back to the individual workplace.

BREAK.PARA: I was a member of the Senate Economics References Committee that heard evidence right across Australia. I was reminded of the evidence given by some very eminent people, and I will refer to what they said. Mr John Hendy QC, Professor Breen Creighton and Professor Keith Ewing, all on behalf of the International Centre for Trade Union Rights, gave evidence to the Senate Economics References Committee that most employers do not want to obtain a competitive advantage by undercutting wages and conditions they accord their employees.

Most employers want the certainty of labour costs provided by the existing system. They seek to compete upon the basis of superior efficiency and quality of service and product. Nevertheless, there are unscrupulous employers, perhaps those who are less able to compete on the basis of quality of service and product, who will welcome this new regulatory regime. Mr Hendy, Professor Creighton and Professor Ewing told us that, instead of encouraging competition between employers on product and service, these new provisions will encourage employers to compete on the pay packet of their employees.

The United States system, which focuses only on the workplace, may be sustainable for the United States. It has a vast economy. It has a vast population. It is certainly not like Australia, which has a relatively small population spread over a vast continent.

The benefits of growth in the economy of the United States have accrued almost exclusively to the top half of one per cent of individuals in the United States. That is, the multimillionaires are doing better than ever in the United States, and at the same time debate raged over whether the minimum wage for US workers would be increased from $4.25 per hour to $5.15—$US4.25 is $A5.70. Full-time workers who earned the minimum wage earned $US8,500, not even half of the official poverty line for a family of four.

The end result of this legislation, based on these objects, will be Australian workers facing the same experiences as workers in the United States. About 3.7 million Americans earn the $4.25 minimum United States rate. Another 10 million earn between $US4.25 and $US5.15, still below the poverty line. The American Democrats wanted to raise the minimum to $5.15. As a compromise, workers on the minimum wage will receive three wage rises of 30c.

That is the same basic system this coalition government and their supporters would like to establish, and all the ingredients in the objects and the details of this legislation over time will allow them to achieve that. It is subtle. They are not like the Hewsons of 1993 when they were going for a big hit; they are now subtle. The details of this legislation will allow these things to happen over time. They know that in individual workplaces there is weakness where people are not able to bargain effectively. When I have another go, I will go into the details of those weaknesses in the objects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the bill first.

—I have read the bill. I have been all over Australia hearing examples of young people, of immigrants, of women particularly, of your state counterparts—indeed, the senator's own state of Western Australia is one of the worst offenders—shameful examples of how people are exploited. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments on the objects clause of the workplace relations bill, currently before the Senate and under consideration. I wish to make five points by way of introduction and, if there is time left, make a couple of other observations.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, it needs to be put on the record that this bill, as proposed to be amended by the Senate, is a backroom deal between the government and the Australian Democrats, with all the connotations that flow from that. Secondly, the bill is opposed by the overwhelming majority of the leadership of the trade union movement of Australia. Thirdly, the bill is specifically designed to hurt low paid and female workers. Fourthly, it is a bill that the Australian Labor Party is proud to repudiate and will continue to repudiate, and when we return to government will seek to overturn. My final observation is that the bill, even with the amendments currently before the Senate, repudiates a significant number of the key Australian Democrats' principles that they put in their supplementary report to the workplace inquiry.

At the conclusion of those five points, I intend to make a few general comments concerning the bill's shameful treatment of female workers and low paid workers. I will also offer an option as to how they can be protected by referring to specific developments in my own state of Western Australia.

I turn firstly to the fact that this is a sleazy, backroom deal negotiated between the government and the Australian Democrats. It was negotiated in private and concluded in secret. The process had no regard for accountability, transparency of process or honesty, despite the election campaigns of the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I rise on a point of order. Today we are debating the workplace relations bill and I think Senator Bishop may be referring to the negotiations over the Native Title Bill. Could you refer him to the workplace relations bill?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Firstly, despite the oft repeated comments about openness of process, both by the government in its election campaign and by the Australian Democrats, those key objectives or principles have been expressly repudiated. Secondly, the bill is indeed opposed by the leadership of the Australian trade union. It has been opposed publicly and condemned by most major trade unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Indeed, looking at today's Australian and the Financial Review of the last two days, you will see that the general officers of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Australian Workers Union, the LHMU, the STA and the CFMEU have all been quite direct and critical of the content of the bill. It has been extensively criticised in both public and private by the ACTU for adding a little dross around the edges.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, this is a bill expressly designed to hurt, harm and disadvantage low paid and female workers. There should be no doubt that it harms the direct financial interests of low paid female workers. These workers may be found, as we all know, in hotels, restaurants, the hospitality industry, process aspects of manufacturing, retail, supermarkets and sales. The Australian Democrats are a party that ostensibly advances the interests of women. It attempts to solicit the union vote and proudly parades the fact that five of its seven members in this place are female. There is no reference in the objects of this bill heeding the interests of this group of workers, and they are explicitly ignored in the bill by that party. This bill deliberately sells this group of people down the river.

Fourthly, this is a bill that the ALP is proud to repudiate: we are proud to reject it, and we are proud to have no part of the amendments proposed by the government and the Australian Democrats. This is a bill that only those two parties can claim title to and ownership of. We are very pleased now, in the medium term and in the long term to be isolated from this vicious piece of legislation.

I would forecast that, over the next six to 18 months, unions in every shop, factory and warehouse will have one thing to say as they explain the meaning and intent of this bill. As people complain of cuts to their hours, loss of guaranteed weekly minimum hours, loss of guaranteed weekly maximum hours when working part time, as they suffer the loss of guaranteed daily minimum hours, guaranteed daily maximum hours and as they suffer a loss of security, there will be only two parties to blame: the government and the Australian Democrats and their leadership. We will be very vociferous in pointing out to every part-time and female worker who suffers a cut of hours where the responsibility lies.

Fifthly, it is clear that the Australian Democrats have paid little heed to the 13 key principles that were outlined in Senator Murray's report. It is true that a number of aspects of those key principles have been incorporated in the agreed amendments which are before the Senate. However, there is no support for a comprehensive up-to-date award system. There is no suggestion that the award system will remain relevant over time.

BREAK.PARA: Additionally, there is a limitation on arbitration, there is no reference to industrial democracy and there is no recognition at all of the legitimate role of trade unions. Members opposite like to swing off and make comments about the fact that trade union membership is somewhere around 30 to 35 per cent of the Australian work force and dominates in key industries and sectors of industries. This bill deliberately ignores that fact. It offers no comfort, no protection, no purpose and no role to those organisations.

Also, there is what can only be described as a `sleazy deal' on secondary boycotts. They are apparently proper and legitimate—authorised to be legal. By definition, public policy is to encourage secondary boycotts of a consumer nature or on environmental issues. But if a worker or group of workers wishes to protect their living standards, wages and health and safety issues, that is to be outlawed. So there is more value in insects—flora and fauna—as has been outlined in other debates, than there is in the working conditions of Australian workers. That apparently is to become public policy in this country in a deal between the government and the Democrats.

Sixthly, there is little protection for part-time workers. Therefore, I will turn to the more distasteful aspects of the bill and the fact that they are not addressed in the objects. Particularly, I will refer to the shameful treatment of part-time and female workers. I will relay to the Senate my experience in Western Australia over the last few years, as we have had a nearly identical system in that state, and I will refer to the submissions of the Commissioner for Workplace Agreements.

It is my direct observation from the independent supermarket industry that my comments are equally valid concerning unskilled workers or low skilled workers anywhere. Unions in awards, enterprise bargaining agreements and certified agreements in low skilled and unskilled industries essentially achieve in negotiations a margin above what the market will pay. That margin extends to wages and conditions and establishes for that group of workers a higher standard of living than they would be able to achieve otherwise. There is no doubt about that, and that is agreed on both sides. That is the purpose of awards—to achieve a rate above that which the market establishes.

Awards of that nature have little relevance to professional people, to high skilled people and to highly educated women. The market sets a high rate for their pay based on skill, and they do not need awards or other instruments to increase it or to maintain it.

In the last three years in Western Australia, as workplace agreements have been introduced in a range of low skill, low value industries, the results have become clear. The market price for retail workers in independent supermarkets and allied firms has fallen by up to $5 per hour. The rate has gone below the award rate, which was in the order of $12 or $13 per hour, down to a rate of $7 to $8 per hour, depending on the suburb and the locality. That rate of $7 to $8 per hour in Australian dollars is remarkably similar to the $5.25, $5.55, permitted in the US minimum wage law.

So the results are clear from Western Australia—perhaps less clear in Victoria because there are not the detailed records—that the introduction of workplace bargaining via individual contracts to low skilled, semi‐skilled and low value industries results in a cutting back of above market wages to market levels of some $7 to $8 per hour. This bill is explicitly designed to achieve that outcome. It is designed to achieve that outcome on the backs of low paid workers who are principally female and in retail and hospitality industries.

For the life of me, I cannot understand why any party—let alone the Australian Democrats, who seek to parade the interests of female workers, of female voters—would deliberately establish a policy and agree to amendments in a bill that would have the direct consequence of decreasing their wages. I can understand why the government would want to do that, and I can understand the financial drive behind that objective. Why the Australian Democrats, with their five female senators, who have proudly outlined their principles in their maiden speeches and other efforts, would seek to drive down the wages of their own gender is beyond me. But that is the direct purpose and will be the obvious outcome of this bill.

In summary, it is proper to highlight the deficiencies in the objects clause. It is entirely proper to sheet home the blame for that to the government, but more particularly to the Australian Democrats, who have engaged in that secret negotiating process which they apparently, until now, have repudiated. It is proper to highlight that the objects of the bill and the express provisions that we will discuss later are designed to harm the interests of low paid workers and female workers in a range of service industries. It is proper to place on the record that we wish to have no part of it, that we oppose it and that we will go into the community and into the workplaces and outline our concerns, explain our principles, and properly and accurately outline what the Australian Democrats and the government have sought to achieve in this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —The workplace relations bill was born out of an ideological obsession by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the coalition parties to devalue the award system of this country, to destroy the role of the trade union movement in this country and to reduce the wages of ordinary workers in this country. Notwithstanding all of the rhetorical flourish of the Prime Minister's policy launch, launched when he was Leader of the Opposition, prior to the election, notwithstanding the high sounding rhetoric of some of the objects of the bill and notwithstanding the recently announced agreement—or secret deal, as Senator Bishop so accurately describes it—one can still see that this bill will damage, maybe irreparably, the position of hundreds of thousands of Australian workers.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly refer to those workers in low paid jobs who rely upon the industrial awards system of this country for protection. Let us remember that we are here today dealing with legislation of the parliament, legislation which the Prime Minister claims is one of the hallmark, central pieces of his government's program.

I have always understood that legislation is about protecting and maintaining the interests and welfare of Australian citizens. That is what the former Conciliation and Arbitration Act and the Industrial Relations Act have been about. Certainly, they are not cast in stone. It is appropriate from time to time for governments and the participants—employers, employees, unions, employer organisations—to look at updating or revising the provisions of that act as circumstances warrant. Indeed, the history of industrial relations in this country is that that has been the process.

Certainly, that was the process engaged in by the former government when it brought in the Industrial Relations Act. It is an act which sought to establish a new development in industrial relations in this country, that is, more emphasis on enterprise bargaining. It is an act which sought to also recognise the increasing complexities of the labour market and international impacts upon it. But at all times it recognised that a fundamental system needed to be retained, that is, a system of industrial awards regulated through the processes of conciliation and arbitration by an independent umpire, namely, the Industrial Relations Commission.

This bill heads in an entirely opposite direction. That is evident when you look at the objects of the act, because what is so stark is what has been removed from the objects of the current act. What is also so stark is the inconsistency—I would suggest hypocrisy—of the coalition government's position with respect to their electoral promises and the legislation now before the Senate. That continues to exist and has not been remedied by the agreement between the government and the Democrats. I have to say to the Democrats that they have walked away from some of their own election promises and pronouncements on this issue. I will come back to that in a minute.

The coalition's industrial relations policy was headed Better pay for better work. The Prime Minister went to great lengths to assure the Australian work force that no worker would be worse off as a result of his zeal to reform—in his words—the labour market. Why is it then that, if one of the twin objectives of this legislation is the achievement of better pay, there is no mention whatsoever in the objects of the act of that fundamental commitment? According to the Prime Minister, two things are supposed to flow from this legislation: firstly, improved employment and, secondly, better pay.

We will see in a couple of years, if not sooner, whether those results were achieved. It is our belief, based upon years of experience, that that will not occur. You would think that, if you were being honest with the Australian people and you were going to stick to your commitments, the one object that would be staring out at you from page 1 of this legislation would be an object to promote better pay. You would also expect an object to be in this act which said that no person, as a result of this legislation, should suffer any diminution in their wages and working conditions and other entitlements. But that is precisely what is going to happen as a result of this legislation. When we get to discuss some of the more specific aspects of the legislation, such as those dealing with allowable matters, you will see very clearly how workers will suffer.

A lot of people place great store upon the objects of legislation. Indeed, it is correct that one should look to the objects of the legislation: firstly, to see what is actually supposed to be achieved by the legislation and, secondly, to see whether it can be an aid in resolving issues relating to a lack of clarification or uncertainty in the legislation.

I can recall what happened in the Senate inquiry proceedings. On a number of occasions when it was pointed out by witnesses that various protections which existed in the current act had been removed, Senator Crane and other members of the coalition said, `Oh, but it's in the objects of the act.' Any industrial relations practitioner with a minimum of experience will tell you that, in the absence of specific provision in the legislation, the objects of the act—no matter how grand—may, nevertheless, deliver nothing. In the absence of specific provisions in legislation, for instance, dealing with matters outside of the 18 allowable matters under section 89A, the objects of the act are not going to enable either the Industrial Relations Commission or the participants in the industrial relations negotiations to fill in the gaps.

Of course, that is what the government wants. What they want to do through this act is force people out of the award system. They say that it is designed to encourage people to utilise enterprise bargaining. The very provisions of section 89A coupled with sections 44 and 45, which prescribes by legislation that awards cannot contain provisions other than those listed, is completely contrary to the so-called object, which is to encourage conciliation—it was as a last resort, but I notice that it is proposed to be amended—and arbitration.

Prior to this bill, the current act placed great emphasis on conciliation and arbitration. We now also have in the act the parallel system of enterprise bargaining. The two have worked very well together, as the recent report of the Industrial Relations Commission indicated. But in this bill conciliation and arbitration has been reduced to a mere by‐line, notwithstanding that the constitutional power for this bill is derived from section 51(xxxv)—that is, the power of the Commonwealth to make laws dealing with the conciliation and arbitration of interstate industrial disputes.

Under this bill, the role of the commission is reduced to virtually a rubber stamp. I am not surprised about that because we have also seen that the other sections of the bill, such as those dealing with the Employment Advocate, were going to be rubber stamp processes too. Nobody was going to have any opportunity to scrutinise whether or not the tests of fairness and of equity had been met.

No doubt we are going to have a lot more opportunity throughout the day to look specifically at some of these objects. But let me just point to a couple of the problems that I see. Firstly, as I have indicated, there is no object which relates in any way to the maintenance and protection of current wages and working conditions of employees. Secondly, this bill removes from the act the existing provision which encourages the registration of democratic organisations of employers and employees. Nothing has been done to restore that position in the deal that has been made between the government and the Democrats.

BREAK.PARA: Might I also say in relation to that deal that I find it hypocritical to the highest degree that legislation which is supposed to be about encouraging employers and employees to negotiate and reach agreement will ultimately, it appears, get through this Senate because of a backroom deal—an agreement where the very participants have had little opportunity or no opportunity to be involved. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I would like to deal with the very first object of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) encouraging the pursuit of high employment, improved living standards, low inflation and international competitiveness through higher productivity and a flexible labour market—

It seems that this government is using this bill as an all‐embracing panacea for the difficulties that this economy is facing. When we have examples of slashing labour market programs like Working Nation, what do we hear from the government? `The Senate should not be obstructive. We should get the workplace relations bill through and that will increase employment growth, productivity and our international competitiveness and all will be well.'

I think it behoves the chamber to look at what is happening in other states, particularly in relation to economic activity. That is what I would like to talk about. As a member of the Senate Economics References Committee that dealt with this bill, I, together with a number of others, travelled around Australia and looked at the various industrial relations systems in the other states and at the overall impact that this bill would have in relation to other states, the economy, workers' rights and so on. As a precursor to that exercise, my office and I worked out precisely what productivity figures were on a state-by-state basis and then matched those to the relevant industrial relations systems that each of those states had. It proved to be a very interesting exercise indeed.

The definition of `productivity' became a bit of a vexed question in the hearings that were held. Because I have an interest in this area, I asked many people who gave submissions, particularly employer groups, what they regarded as the definition of `productivity'. Quite frankly, their definition of `productivity' was probably best put by the chamber of commerce from my own state. They said, `Senator, how long is a piece of string?'
