After some considerable time in debate with them, they have satisfied me that that is the case and that this scientific research should go ahead. I think I certainly tried to meet all the legal prerequisites. But I am more than happy to open my books to you, Senator, and you can make that assessment for yourself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for that answer, Minister. I just want to ask you about the validity of a research project which opens up the remaining four per cent of protected areas when you already have 96 per cent open. How valid is it to cause damage in the name of research for what you want to do—extend fishing?

—I am sorry, Senator, but you have missed the point, which obviously is the result of an inadequacy in my answer—and I have to concede that. The point is that I do not want to extend fishing; I want to protect the fish stocks on the reef—
—By extending the fishing?

—and I actually want to protect them not only from an industry perspective but also from a conservation perspective. But the scientists have argued to me—and they have convinced me—that you have to have something to compare to be satisfied that the current levels of fishing are not threatening the sustainability of the species. That is the point. So it is quite the congruous of what you say. The purpose of providing this comparison is to ensure that we are adequately conserving fish on the reef, and I am more than happy to continue this debate afterwards.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, representing both the Prime Minister and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service. Do you agree with the comments made by the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Max Moore-Wilton, when he described the federal Public Service Act as `a dog's breakfast of arcane, outdated and cumbersome regulation'? In the light of these comments, will the government be considering the introduction of individual work contracts for public servants in order to achieve, in the words of Mr Max Moore-Wilton, `more flexible remuneration'? Also, would part of this more flexible remuneration include the payment of differential wage rates for public servants doing the same job but in different states, as is suggested by Mr Moore-Wilton?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Each uses language of an individual's choice. I have witnessed a lot of frustration in the Public Service and difficulties in relation to work conditions. Interestingly, at the end of the last parliament—just before you got here—we tabled in this place the latest information on income levels which showed that lower paid public servants were actually falling further behind. Interestingly, under Labor higher paid public servants did well and lower paid public servants did not do as well. I guess it reflects the attitude of Labor to the community at large. Under Labor the rich got richer and the poor got poorer.

ANSWER.PARA: If Mr Max Moore-Wilton is talking about a system that does provide greater flexibility, greater incentive and greater personal reward—it is not just in terms of remuneration; it can be in terms of job satisfaction as well—then I can see considerable merit in what he is suggesting.

Again, the problem with Labor is that they are so busy to tell but so slow to listen. Public servants have been coming to this parliament expressing their frustrations about their conditions and terms of employment. We have even had parliamentary inquiries to explore these difficulties. But you are not interested in that. You just want to make a cheap political point. We are interested in the welfare of public servants in the way that we are interested in the welfare of all Australians.

PARA.BREAK: We will not simply accept that the work conditions of the past are necessarily the best. If they can be improved, we would want to see them improved. That is part of our re sponsibility to public servants whom you ignored for far too long.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do you further agree with Mr Moore-Wilton when he stated that the Public Service Act was `a tangible obstacle to a modern and thoroughly efficient Commonwealth public sector', and are we to assume from Mr Moore-Wilton's comments that the Australian Public Service is both thoroughly inefficient and in desperate need of modernisation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Mr Reith is working on improvements to the act that will improve the lot of public servants. I guess that we are interested in two things: we are interested in efficiency of outcome in terms of the administration of the government's program, and we are interested in the wellbeing, job satisfaction, remuneration and terms and conditions of employment of the public service. Because, Senator Lundy—you may not be prepared to concede it—both issues are interrelated.

ANSWER.PARA: You need to provide an environment within which your staff can feel that they are getting adequately rewarded—in their work conditions, their training, their opportunity for advancement and provisions that can meet their frustrations. At the same time, you need to give them reward, and out of that you get better performance. So they are interrelated. We are prepared to pick up the challenge and do something that you were not prepared to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The minister will be aware that in the past week there have been three Aboriginal deaths in custody in Queensland. This raises the question of the effectiveness of the programs to deal with this problem. Some $400 million has already been spent on implementing the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, yet the number of deaths continues to rise. Can the minister advise whether the government has any plans to attempt to deal with this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator O'Chee for the question. Yes, I am aware of the recent tragedies in Queensland. The latest death occurred in the Sir David Longland Correctional Centre and involved 30-year-old Edmund Auda. Mr Auda was found hanging from the bars of his cell on Monday morning. I understand that he had been transferred to Queensland from the Northern Territory in 1991. He had been released to work on 17 January 1996 but returned to custody on 3 April after being charged with various counts, including indecent assault and rape.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Auda was housed in a single cell in the Murri unit at the Sir David Longland Correctional Centre and was due to face court yesterday. I am sure that all senators share my concern that there has been a continuing high rate of deaths in custody since the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody released its findings. Compounding the problem, of course, is that incarceration rates for indigenous people continue to be at an unacceptably high level. This is particularly so with young indigenous people.

The only conclusion that can be reached is that the process of implementing the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody has not effectively addressed these issues. This government came into office with the commitment to hold a Commonwealth-state summit on Aboriginal deaths in custody and the causes for the continuing high incarceration rates.

Through the staff of my office, ATSIC, the Attorney-General's office and department, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Office of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, we formed a steering committee that meets regularly to plan the summit. A consultation process involving indigenous communities and organisations will be coordinated by the Aboriginal Justice Advisory Committee in the lead-up to the summit.

An indigenous preparatory meeting will be held on 17 and 18 February next year prior to the summit, which is scheduled for 1 and 2 May 1997. The ministerial summit is open to Commonwealth and state territory ministers with responsibilities for indigenous affairs, law and justice, policing and corrective services and juvenile justice. The intended outcome of the summit is that there will be a renewed commitment by all Australian governments to reduce both indigenous deaths in custody and incarceration rates.

The areas identified for discussion in consultation with Aboriginal justice advisory committees are juvenile justice, diversionary strategies and policing in prisons. Obviously, Senator O'Chee and the Senate will acknowledge that—unless there is involvement of the Aboriginal people in the process, and their advice should be taken—no changes will occur in this regard until we get an effective strategy that has the support of the indigenous community itself, particularly in keeping young indigenous offenders out of custody.

There has been considerable discussion in that regard as to the manner in which this can occur. There have been pilot programs whereby young offenders are taken not into custody but to facilities where they are trained in work activities. This allows them to be trained in horse breaking and in activities that will give them the encouragement to enter the work force. So useful occupations will ensue out of this and also give them the opportunity of access to their family members, which was one of the major factors involved in the process.

The summit is in line with recommendations 62 and 188 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I would hope that—as a result of this process and the summit that does occur with the involvement of indigenous people—an effective outcome can be achieved where at long last, after the expenditure of that vast sum, something can be achieved. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 October, Senator Harradine asked me three questions in regard to genetic manipulation in my capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. The Minister for Science and Technology has provided an answer to the honourable senator's question. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
SENATOR HARRADINE asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, on 17 October 1995:
(1) What restrictions are placed on genetic manipulation to avoid the dangers of the inadvertent creation of super resistant diseases?
(2) What mandatory reporting requirements are there for GMAC, the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Council, to be advised of the risks?
(3) What reporting procedures are there for the minister to be kept informed and advised of dangerous incidents or potentially dangerous incidents involving genetically engineered organisms?
SENATOR PARER —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) Any individual or organisation intending to carry out genetic manipulation work is required to observe the requirements of the guidelines issued by the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC). These include submitting a proposal for the intended work for review by Institutional Biosafety Committees and by GMAC. GMAC assesses proposals for genetic manipulation work on a case-by case basis. It takes into consideration any potential risks that the work might pose to human health, as well as environmental risks. GMAC would advise that a proposal should not proceed if these risks were significant and could not be managed.
Since GMAC is a non-statutory body, its recommendations do not have the force of law.

There are legal controls on research into the deliberate creation and storage of quantities of disease organisms for the purposes of biological warfare, whether this be by genetic engineering or by other means.
Section 8.(1) of the Crimes (Biological Weapons) Act 1976 provides that:
"It is unlawful to develop, produce, stockpile or the wise acquire or retain:

PARA.TAB: (a) microbial or other biological agents, or toxins whatever their origin or method of production of types and in quantities that have no justification for prophylactic, protective or other peaceful purposes;"

QUESTION.PARA: (2) The risks associated with proposals for genetic manipulation work are assessed by GMAC on a case-by-case basis. GMAC's guidelines also require that institutions undertaking genetic manipulation work submit an annual report to GMAC of their activities, including a report on breaches of the guidelines or any significant accident or incident relating to health of workers which may reasonably be attributed directly to genetic manipulation work. Accidents or breaches must also be reported to the head of the institution and to GMAC as soon as the institution becomes aware of them. For proposals involving the planned release into the environment of genetically manipulated organisms, GMAC requires submission of a report on the planned release after its completion.

(3) GMAC's terms of reference requires it to advise the minister about matters affecting the regulation of innovative genetic manipulation technology and to provide the minister annually a review of the risks associated with genetic manipulation technology; and a report on the activities of GMAC. To fulfil these requirements, GMAC produces an annual report for tabling in parliament. The annual report includes a report of any accidents or incidents (including breaches of GMAC's Guidelines) which directly compromised safety, where supervision of the work was unsatisfactory, or when an accident involving genetic manipulation occurred which might jeopardise the health of workers. As well, GMAC briefs the minister as soon as it becomes aware of any breaches of its guidelines or incidents that represent a significant risk to human or environmental safety.
The health portfolio also has related responsibilities. I understand that the honourable senator has written to the Minister for Health on gene technology issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October, Senator Stott Despoja asked me a question about a World Bank report that was apparently referred to in a committee hearing that morning. I undertook to get some more information. I have some of that information now.

QUESTION.PARA: The claims made by Senator Stott Despoja in the question—and, I think, subsequently in a press release—were, firstly, that the report recommends that students in public universities should not be charged more than 30 per cent of the costs of their study and, secondly, that the proposed new HECS charges would mean that Australia's public universities were to become the most expensive in the Western world. Indeed, the Senator did put out a press release captioned `Australia's universities most expensive in Western world'.

Following these claims, my office and the department looked at the study, and I was informed that both of these allegations were without foundation. No, the World Bank report did not make a general recommendation applicable to all countries. It made a qualified recommendation for Latin-American countries. It recommends that a target contribution level of 25 to 30 per cent of tuition costs reflects the recognition of `the prevailing pattern of income level and distribution in these countries'. That is on page 44.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one you are referring to is on page 45. Page 44 is the other one.

—Senator, I am happy for you to come back and have something further to say if you have a different view about this. Given that the reference, which I think is on page 44, refers to the recognition of `the prevailing pattern of income level and distribution in these countries'—which is referring to Latin-American countries—I do not think it is appropriate to say that this is a yardstick across the board.

QUESTION.PARA: Equally, I think it is incorrect to assert on the basis of this report that only in Korea would students enrolled in public universities be contributing proportionally more than Australian students. I understand, Senator, that you may be referring to the World Bank study table comparing tuition fees as a proportion of recurrent expenditures. If that is the case, it is very important to examine the table in that report very carefully. What that table does is compare fees as a proportion of total recurrent expenditure, not as a proportion of total tuition cost; that is, recurrent expenditure includes many activities other than tuition—in particular, research. That ratio should not be confused with the proportion of tuition costs recovered by the HECS scheme.

We have estimated that on average with the benefits, taking into account the benefits of the implicit interest subsidy under the deferral option used by some—that is, the deferral of their payment—and the up-front discount used by others, students will contribute, on average, about 27 per cent of the cost of their tuition. Obviously, Senator, you can look at one course or another course and you will find percentages lower than that and higher than that. That is, quite obviously, what an average is: it is an average of things that are higher than that point and lower than that point.

Senator, I am particularly grateful to you for drawing my attention to the World Bank report, because it has a range of other comments that are of relevance to the current higher education debate in Australia, which you have not yet referred to. That may be because you have not yet had a chance to go through the whole report. Maybe you, like I, did not have a copy of it when you asked your question. Nonetheless, for example, it argues that some positive examples demonstrate:
It is possible to achieve a well‐functioning, diversified, growing higher education system, even as public spending per student declines.

In fact, in Australia, of course, public spending per student will effectively be maintained. Senator, that should inspire great confidence, given that the report that you refer to says that you can do all of these things with declining expenditures per student. In Australia, we do not have effectively declining expenditures per student, so you should be happy. I think this next point is particularly relevant, Senator, because it goes on to point out:
The children of the well-off are heavily subsidised by the rest of society to attend public universities, reinforcing their social and economic advantage.

As you well know, Senator, it is the children of higher socioeconomic families who largely get into university. It is those children who are enjoying the very large subsidies of other taxpayers. This report says that by continuing that, in effect, it means:
The children of the well-off are heavily subsidised by the rest of society to attend public universities, reinforcing their social and economic advantage.
The third point I want to draw to your attention is the comment in the report that gives considerable support to universities reducing their dependence on governments—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got the paper?

—No, I do not—both going to industry sources and relying on student contributions. It points out that student contributions `create important incentives for students to select their programs of study carefully and to complete their courses more rapidly'.

BREAK.PARA: That is not the last thing I want to point out. There is just one more that I would like to raise today, Senator. I think there is a very rich field in this report. I would like to have a greater opportunity to look at it. Last but not least, it says:
Because students in higher education tend to come from higher income groups, a large publicly funded higher education system tends to have adverse effects on income distribution.
The next sentence is particularly important vis-a-vis the HECS changes:
The need to implement comprehensive reform is widely acknowledged.

Senator, I conclude by saying that, if you put so much faith in this report, you will accept that it says that the children of the well off are the most subsidised by a publicly funded higher education system, you will accept that we are asking those students therefore to pay more to reduce the subsidy and you will understand that, because it is largely the children of people who are well off who are heavily subsidised, that, by refusing to support the increases in HECS and a differentiated HECS, you will be reinforcing the social and economic advantage that those students receive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement.

—On a point of order, Madam President. It is the opposition's usual practice to grant leave. I am sure we would grant leave to Senator Newman to make a statement, but it is ordinary to have some sort of understanding of what the statement is about and how long it is likely to take. No‐one has indicated informally to us—
—Or informally.
—I said `informally'—what this is about. While it would ordinarily be our intention to grant leave, that is not the usual form of the Senate.
—I apologise to the opposition for that. It is a very short statement. I wish to amplify some matters that are on the public record in the Senate.
—About what? What is it about?
—About my office.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time today and on previous days, issues were raised about the fit-out of my office in Launceston. It was suggested certainly by interjection today—I do not know whether it was in the question—that I had criticised Tasmanian tradespeople. I did nothing of the sort.
—Oh, cut it out.
—I want that most emphatically on the record because I have serious criticisms of elements of the Department of Administrative Services who were responsible for the fit-out of my office.
—They were workers.

—They were not the workers; they were the supervisors, Senator. The supervisors came from Hobart for a job that was being undertaken in Launceston and the workers were not supervised to the extent that, as I said in my answer the other day, there was a shambles. That was caused quite clearly by a lack of planning by the Department of Administrative Services and by a lack of supervision by those officers.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor Party senators are demonstrating by this little effort that they are humbugs because the total cost of the fit‐out of my office was quite moderate in comparison with the fit-out costs of other MPs. I draw your attention to other Tasmanian fit-outs: Senator Murphy, who asked the question, $109,500—Senator Murphy, where was your cost control? Where was your interest in the taxpayers' interest?; Senator Lundy, who has only just had her office fitted out, $104,000; Senator Mackay, $64,000—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President. I understand now why Senator Newman did not give any indication to the Senate about what matter she wished to address us on. It seems to me that it would be appropriate, given that this issue was canvassed in question time, for a senator to move that the Senate take note of Senator Newman's answer. I understand that is the intention of Senator Murphy. It would be perfectly competent and proper in my view for this sort of contribution to be made by Senator Newman in that debate.

INTERJECT.PARA: I do believe that we are now straying into an area which I think would be rather unfortunate. It would not be the opposition's intention in the future to give leave to ministers to widely canvass matters that have been dealt with in question time unless they believe they have been misrepresented.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not seek leave on that basis, Senator; you sought leave to make a short statement in relation to yourself, whatever that means.

INTERJECT.PARA: The point of order I take is a serious one. I believe this is bordering on an abuse of the leave that was granted by the chamber. I do not argue that Senator Newman has a right to make the contribution that she wants to make in the appropriate way, which would be speaking to the motion that Senator Murphy intends to move.

I ask Senator Newman to give very serious consideration to that in the spirit of the way that these matters have been handled previously in the chamber. Senator Newman, if this continues, then you will not have that level of generosity of spirit from the opposition nor could any minister expect it in these circumstances.

I do not believe that the point of order I am making is unreasonable in these circumstances. It is perfectly proper. I would ask you to give very serious consideration to it and to rule accordingly, Madam President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman sought leave to make a statement and leave was granted without restriction. Had it been a matter of making a personal explanation, if that had been the case, I would suggest that Senator Newman has gone beyond making a personal explanation, but that was not a requirement at the time. I would just draw to Senator Newman's attention the places within the Senate processes where the matter could also be raised if it were to be debated.

—Thank you, Madam President. I would like to move, therefore, on to the detail of the fit‐out—or refitting again—of my office. Following the federal election and my appointment to cabinet, there was a need for more office space to accommodate extra ministerial staff in my Launceston electorate office, which I have used since my election to the Senate in 1986. Discussions started in March with a DAS officer based in Hobart. Rather than fit‐out and relocate to a new office at considerable expense and effort, it was decided to occupy the lower floor of the same building. Some security work was also carried out by Asset Services.

SPEECH.PARA: In mid‐May I finally received a formal fit‐out plan from Works Australia. Some discussions were held with a DAS interior designer who then went on three weeks holiday overseas and was never heard from again. There was no handover to anybody else in the DAS office, and there was no knowledge. Heating was disconnected and heater covers were removed on 4 June. The entire office area was left without heating in a Launceston winter. No replacement was provided, and my staff had to bring their own small fan heaters from home. The electrical wiring for the heaters—

TALK.START.PARA: —Your workers were cold.
—Yes, my workers were cold for two weeks in the middle of a Launceston winter. The electrical wiring for the heaters was left exposed, which of course is dangerous.

SPEECH.PARA: On 11 June the contracted carpet layers arrived from Hobart. Why Hobart tradesmen were engaged for Launceston, I do not know. They wanted to do the job in one day so that they could return to Hobart the same night. Works Australia had in fact scheduled the job over a couple of days, to commence the next day. There were no removalists organised to move furniture and office equipment so carpet layers were delayed and unhappy and had to wait for the removalists. So the removalists and my own three office staff spent the rest of the day moving furniture and equipment to allow carpet laying, and the job continued until at least midnight. It is worth noting that my staff assisted the removalists against the instructions of Works Australia operating out of Hobart.

Electricians arrived on 17 June to do the rewiring for the lighting, communications, phones and computers. This required pulling up the newly laid carpet as they required access under floorboards in order to put wiring through walls and ceilings for the lower floor. Again the removalists had to be called in to assist with the moving of furniture and equipment with the help of staff. It was then necessary for the office to be closed for two days. Wiring work was continued on 20 June, and the carpet, now looking the worse for wear, was being relaid. Some office furniture was put back in place and the rest had to be despatched to storage for the duration of the refit. Some of the carpet had to be lifted for a third time for some extra wiring work due to the poor planning.

When the painting, wiring and final carpet laying was finished, the office furniture was moved back from storage. There were still a number of outstanding deficiencies. The fittings for the lighting in the downstairs offices were excessively large compared to what had been ordered.

TALK.START.PARA: —My point of order is that the minister is reading from a document, contrary to the standing orders.
—What a pathetic point of order!
—This is something that, if you have got a statement, could easily have been incorporated in Hansard . This is an abuse of Senate processes, and you know it. Four paragraphs!
—Ministers are allowed to read matters that other senators would not be allowed to read.

—However, I do not want to tire the Senate. I find it a very tiring and infuriating saga that taxpayers' funds should be wasted by people who are charged with the prudent management of them: that was Works Australia, a segment of the Department of Administrative Services. Despite what I heard from the opposition at question time, the project was not finally completed until late September. It was supposedly started straight after the election in March. The entire project was plagued by poor direction and management by Works Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much noise in the chamber.
—It was not plagued by changes of instruction from me. In fact, because the—
—Don't come in here again asking for leave. She will. She'll be asking for leave for her second reading speech—and she won't get it!
—Senator Faulkner!

—This is only delaying the matter. The problem is that I did not change the specifications as we went along. They were given to the original Works Australia representative at the beginning, and she hied it off to the Pacific and never came back. Her poor successor did not know any of this detail and had to go through it all again and guess what some of it was meant to be, because I was very busily engaged at that time in Canberra, getting on top of the portfolio of social security, as you well know.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, I was not in the office very much at all, and I was certainly not bothering any workmen. There was certainly extra cost because of the lack of supervision by Works Australia. Nevertheless, having said all that, the total was still miles less than for my colleagues in Tasmania. For Senator Murphy, as I just pointed out, it was about $109,000, Senator Lundy, $104,000—

TALK.START.PARA: —She is not a Tasmanian.

—No, she is not a Tasmanian, but that is what has had to be spent on Senator Lundy. Mr Duncan Kerr, as a minister, had $114,000 spent on his office fit‐out. Senator Sherry as a parliamentary secretary only had $86,000 spent on his fit‐out. So the fit‐out on my office was moderate, but it should have been much less. Anybody who has to raise carpets over and over again, anybody who provides expensive lighting which is not what is required, should be ashamed of themselves.
—I draw your attention to the state of the chamber, Madam President.
—A quorum is present.
—Isn't it a fact in the standing orders that someone calling a quorum when a quorum is present is ejected for the rest of the day? Could you give us a ruling on that?
—I hope so!
—It is not the fact that that is the consequence, but Senator Faulkner perhaps needs to learn to count. Are there any motions to take note of answers?

—Madam President, before you get to that, I seek your guidance because I would like to know whether I am permitted to comment on the contribution Senator Newman has just made. I would like to take note of this statement.
—You would be able by leave to seek to comment on the matters that Senator Newman has just commented upon.
—I seek leave, Madam President.
—Senator Murphy has sought leave to make a statement on the same matter. Is leave granted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to what Senator Newman has just said, there are two important matters here in terms of the ministerial code of conduct that relates to ministers. I remind Senator Newman that the ministerial code of conduct, which your government has made much ado about, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the parliament or the public. Any misconception caused inadver tently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity.
Senator Newman says she did not condemn any of the tradespeople or, indeed, the workers. I would like to read from page 4553 of the Hansard of 28 October, where Senator Newman said in part:
I was extraordinarily surprised by how inefficient the fit‐out—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President.
—You take a point of order on someone reading from the Hansard ! What a dope!
—As I said, Senator Newman said on page 4553:

SPEECH.PARA: I was extraordinarily surprised by how inefficient the fit‐out people were and by how—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?
—Senator Abetz, we will get to the rest of it in a minute. If that does not refer to the tradespeople, then I do not know what does. Senator Newman went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The taxpayers would be appalled to know how many times very clear instructions were ignored and work had to be redone.
She went on further to say, with regard to the lighting:
The amount of lighting that was put into the office was not what I asked for. There was an excessive amount of lighting and I find that a gross waste of taxpayers' money as well.
Altogether, if ever there was justification for closing down part of the Department of Administrative Services, that was a classic example.

The inference and the reflection on both the department and the workers in Senator Newman's answer yesterday was that, regardless of the cost, the cost of the fit‐out was due to the stuff‐ups that she claimed happened. Your staff member, Senator Newman, reiterated again today that, indeed, the cost of the fit‐out could have been reduced by half had it not been for the stuff‐ups. Minister, that is totally incorrect. That is a gross misrepresentation of the facts and, indeed, a total misleading of this parliament and of the public. The reality is the responsible minister, Mr Jull, approved a budget for a fit‐out of only part of your office, not the total fit‐out but an extension to your office, as you said yesterday.

Quite frankly, I do not have a problem with the cost. It is not a worry to me because I think it is fair and reasonable. I think that ministers, as you pointed out yesterday, do have additional floor space. I feel you are entitled to it if you do your job. You said and your staff have reiterated your words that the cost was due to stuff‐ups. As I said, Minister Jull approved a budget of $60,000 for fit‐out only of the extension of your office. Contrary to what you said, the cost came in at less than $60,000—I think it was $53,400 or something—and, indeed, came in on time.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true and the department says it is not true.

—Senator Newman, yesterday you were asked to prove your point by supplying the documentation. You are yet to supply the documentation that would prove that the claims you make are right. You said yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: I would be very happy, in fact, to supply the opposition with all of the details of the stuff‐ups that occurred in the fit‐out of my office so that they would know what bad management we inherited—

TALK.START.PARA: —And I have done that, just now.
—No, you haven't, Senator Newman.
—Senator Murphy, would you direct your remarks through the chair, if you don't mind.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President. Through you, Senator Newman has not done that. Indeed, I think you may have been requested by another honourable senator in this place and you have not provided any information in that respect. I say again: your office fit‐out was done within the budget that was allocated and approved by the minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr Deputy President, clearly Senator Newman does not have any idea because, in all the fit‐outs of everybody's offices, the Minister for Administrative Services approves a budget and, of course, Senator Newman's budget which was approved by the minister was $60,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman implied, and reflected upon Works Australia and the workers and the tradespeople, that the total cost of the fit‐out was due entirely to `stuff‐ups'. Again, that is clearly a misrepresentation of the facts because in all construction work where there is a problem or where something has been done incorrectly—where there has been, if there was, a so-called stuff‐up—there can be no increase in the cost because the work will be done at no extra cost. But Senator Newman blatantly came in here yesterday and misled the parliament by saying there were increased costs due to stuff‐ups when, in fact, that is entirely wrong.

I go back to the ministerial code of conduct. The minister has a responsibility. If she cannot prove the argument that she has put and the claims that she has made, she has a responsibility to apologise to the people that she has reflected upon and apologise to this chamber for misleading it. That is the reality.

I turn to the claims that Senator Newman made again today about wiring being left, I think she said, exposed. Quite frankly, that is a blatant misleading and a blatant misrepresentation because that simply would not occur. That is a reflection on the tradespeople—the electricians—who actually did the work. I would suggest to Senator Newman, through you, Mr Deputy President, that we contact the electricians—the contractors—who did the work, and ask them whether or not—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they the ones who called her Hyacinth Bucket?
—Absolutely—Hyacinth Bucket! That is exactly right. Poor old Richard. I do not know where he is but he is not in the picture yet.

SPEECH.PARA: There is the heating issue. Senator Newman says that her office and her office staff were left without heating. I would suggest that that is no-one's fault other than Senator Newman's. I do not think any senator can stand up in this chamber and say that, where they have requested provision of services and goods by the department, they have not been—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. We on this side are most anxious to ensure that Senator Murphy be heard in silence because of the embarrassment he is occasioning to himself. Could I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to ask the Labor senators to remain silent and hear their colleague in silence so that we can all hear the embarrassment that he is occasioning himself.
—Order! There is no point of order, but I would ask honourable senators who are wandering around and standing in the aisles to take a seat.

—Most senators would acknowledge that there has always been a readiness on the part of the department, particularly when it relates to the comfort of staff for heating or additional equipment; the department has always been very helpful. I found that particularly the case in Tasmania. I would say, again, that that is just a total misrepresentation.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, with regard to the point that Senator Newman made about the lighting, Senator Newman said:
The amount of lighting that was put into that office was not what I asked for. There was an excessive amount of lighting and I find that a gross waste of taxpayers' money as well.

I would suggest that maybe Senator Newman talk to Minister Jull and ask him about a letter I understand he may have received to ascertain that that amount of lighting was fitted into the office because there are Australian standards that must be complied with. You, Senator Newman, through you, Mr Deputy President, requested specific lighting because of the nature of the building. When they started the work they discovered that there was a false ceiling in the building, which is part of an old building, and they had to change the nature of the lighting, which gives the appearance that there is an excessive amount of lighting. But that has to be the case to comply with the Australian occupational health and safety standards. That is about workers.

BREAK.PARA: Again, Senator Newman has clearly misled this parliament. She has made a claim that is totally false. The minister ought to be called upon to apologise to the Senate for doing it. More importantly, she should be called upon to apologise to the workers she has reflected upon. This really raises the question with regard to the Department of Administrative Services and the minister responsible.

I just have to wonder whether or not the Minister for Administrative Services will ever stand up for the workers that he represents and the department that he represents. Quite clearly, he is not prepared to do so. He is prepared to allow a minister in this Senate to get up and condemn them without any defence from him. If there ever was a person who should take a good look at themselves and this claim about representing workers, it is Minister Jull.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to comment on the same matter.
—You have to take note of the answer.
—I will take note of the answer then.
—We are not there yet.

—Mr Deputy President, I would like to raise a point of order with regard to something that Senator Newman said before. I would like the Hansard checked with regard to what Senator Newman said about the fit‐out of my office. I would like to know whether she said that the cost of the fit‐out was $109,000 or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Murphy today, relating to the refurbishment of Senator Newman's electorate office.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did yours cost?

—Mine was actually very modest compared to Senator Abetz's—$64,000 which came from Senator Newman herself. I think Senator Abetz's was $90,000 and Senator Newman's was $70,000, which was actually a refit‐out of an existing office.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot believe what I have heard here today. When in doubt, blame somebody else! Senator Newman has a reputation for when in doubt, where there is a difficulty or when she gets into hot water, she blames somebody else. Yesterday it was the workers. Today it is the supervisor who went off to hide in the Pacific apparently.

TALK.START.PARA: —How dare she!

—How dare she! She was probably on annual leave. How dare she go off and hide in the Pacific! Then by way of interjection, Senator Newman, in response to Senator Murphy's comments on the budget, said, `Well, it was a stupid budget.' So Mr Jull gets a bucket—no pun intended.
—A bucket from Bucket.
—A bucket from Bucket. Mr Jull gets a bucket.
—Is that a bucket or a bouquet?

—A bouquet or a bucket, I am not sure—certainly not a bouquet. Here we have Senator Newman, when she gets in a bit of hot water, as usual blaming anybody else except herself. The bottom line is this: yesterday, Senator Murphy was absolutely correct. Senator Newman did in fact talk about Tasmanian workers. She talked Tasmanian workers down at a time when this state—my state of Tasmania, her state of Tasmania—has the highest unemployment rate in the country and the highest youth unemployment rate in the country. I am sure that Senator Newman would feel that these people are privileged to have a job.

SPEECH.PARA: What do they get for their pains? They get criticised by not only a Tasmanian senator but a minister. I think that is outrageous. They get criticised by a minister, who, incidentally, we have heard more from over the last two days talking about her office than we have heard from her at all in relation to the impact of the budget on Tasmania. Senator Newman along with Senator Abetz and Senator Calvert were completely silent on the impact of the federal budget on Tasmania, to the extent that Premier Rundle, one of your own party, actually criticised you for being silent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Mackay is addressing her comments to the senator across the chamber. She should be directing them through you and I ask you to ask her to do so.
—She was about to do so. I would appeal to honourable senators who are standing or leaning to take a seat.

—As I said, we have heard more from Senator Newman over the last two days on her office than we have heard from her about the impact of this budget on the whole of the state of Tasmania. Through you, Mr Deputy President, I ask Senator Newman: who do you think elected you? Through you, Mr Deputy President: you are there to represent the people of Tasmania—not to worry about what kind of desk you have, what kind of table you have or whether the crockery falls off because it is—

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. The senator may have prefaced her first comment by the words `through you' but then she continued to address her comments to Senator Newman across the chamber. I ask you to ask her to direct her comments through you.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy President: might I also ask that when you ask Senator Mackay to address her comments to the chair you also ask Senator Newman not to indicate in `this fashion' to Senator Mackay; she should direct her comments to you.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy President: Hansard is going to have great trouble in recording the gesture indicated by Senator Jacinta Collins and I would ask you to ask her to explain that finger movement for the purposes of Hansard .
—I ask for the finger to be withdrawn, Mr Deputy President!
—Order! After all that, I ask Senator Mackay to direct her comments through the chair.

—Obviously there is a bit of sensitivity in relation to this issue—lots of points of order, lots of interjections. Why is there this sensitivity? Well, it is not as sensitive as the people of Tasmania are about how this budget has affected them. Through you, Mr Deputy President, I say to Senator Newman: where was Senator Newman when the cuts to job programs were announced? Where was Senator Newman when the cuts to the University of Tasmania were announced? Where was Senator Newman when the cuts to Working Nation were announced? Where was Senator Newman when the Mowbray DSS office was closed?
—It hasn't been; it's still there, you silly thing.
—I apologise—Mowbray CES office. That is more in relation to your offer—
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Would you please ask the senator to withdraw the misrepresentation about the DSS office? It is still in operation and it has been revamped, as well.
—Minister, you know that is not a point of order.

—Just to conclude, in my view Tasmanians deserve better than a born to rule silvertail representing them, who is completely silent in relation to budget implications—born to rule or born to shop perhaps. All I will say to Senator Newman, through you, Mr Deputy President, is: you would do better to represent the interests of your state rather than worry so much about your office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been here for nine years and I have never heard a dissertation like that in my life in this place. The accusations made against Senator Newman were not only spurious; they were absolutely wrong.
—How would you know?

—The accusation about the Mowbray office for a start is absolutely wrong. Let us get back to what this is all about. On Monday in question time, Senator Denman, a Tasmanian, obviously set out to get a headline in the Mercury —in the local paper—and they gave it to her. The question was:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you think it is appropriate for the Minister for Social Security, in these times of financial stringency, to have spent $53,761 on fitting out your ministerial office and $15,345 on furniture.
One of the interjections from Senator Collins was:
You could buy a house in Launceston for the same price.

And it went on. I looked through the answers that Senator Newman gave and time and time again she spoke about professional supervision, about the Department of Administrative Services and the way that they did not supervise this correctly.

When you look at the costs that were involved you see that, of the $53,000 spent on the fit-out, $31,000 was for electrical work. Senator Newman has been in that office for over 10 years—I have visited it on many occasions—and it is an old house. It is certainly not grand. Half the time you have to sit outside on the veranda at the back to get a bit of extra room.

Senator Newman was trying to save the taxpayer money by fitting out a couple of old rooms underneath for her staff. Most of the money was taken up in electrical work. I guess, if you had had a professional quote done on that place in the first instance, they probably would have advised the minister against doing anything. They probably would have advised her to move somewhere else. Senator Newman, being a true Tasmanian, spent $17,000 on new furniture for extra staff. I looked through the $17,000 and saw where the furniture came from. It came from Tasmanian Executive Furniture. It is all Tasmanian furniture.

Let us have a look at some of these other figures. Senator Sherry, when he had his fit-out, spent $27,000 on furniture. You could buy a house in Launceston for that, Senator Collins. That is $10,000 more than Senator Newman spent. Let us have a look at former minister Duncan Kerr, who only had to move into the Commonwealth offices in Hobart. The offices were already there; all they needed was a fit-out. There was $80,000 spent just on fit-out. We are talking about ministers. How much do you reckon he spent on furniture? He spent $33,000. That is almost the amount the minister spent on all the electrical work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he bucket the workers? Did he talk about `stuff-ups'?
—Senator Newman did not attack the workers. She attacked the department and the professional supervision, and she had every right to do so.
—Did she?

—She certainly did, if you had been listening to what Senator Newman had to say about the mess-ups that were made in lifting up the carpet and all the electrical stuff. I feel sorry for everybody concerned. Obviously the whole fit-out was not planned and carried out correctly.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we have Senator Murphy trying to raise the matter again, trying to get another headline in the paper. That is what it is all about. It is a political stunt that the Labor Party has tried to pull against the minister from Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Calvert is clearly misleading the house. I have not raised the issue for the purposes of getting a headline or otherwise. I raised it on the basis of the ministerial code of conduct. Ministers have an obligation to be honest with this chamber in the comments they make.
—That is a point of view, Senator Murphy, not a point of order. There is no point of order.
—I ask the senator to withdraw that unparliamentary remark that you would have heard, Mr Deputy President.
—There is so much noise in this chamber that it is very hard to hear anything, so I did not hear an unparliamentary remark.

—It is the sort of abuse you usually get from that side. In conclusion, I would like to clarify an accusation that was made by Senator Mackay against Senator Newman, reflecting on a lack of ability to work for Tasmania, which I think is a bit of a joke.

SPEECH.PARA: Only yesterday I gave notice of a motion which, in stark contrast to what the Labor Party had done to Tasmania, highlighted the great effect of the Tasmania package, in particular the freight equalisation payment made to passenger ferries, which your lot never did, and the tremendous contribution that is making to tourism in Tasmania, which is something the Labor Party never talked about. To reflect on Senator Newman in such terms after the work she has done for Tasmania in putting together the Tasmania package, which is something the Labor Party could never do, I think is a bit rich coming from Senator Mackay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the motion to take note of this answer, I want to return to the question of the minister's responsibility. I think it was the minister representing Minister Jull whose answer is being taken note of.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have to recall that one of the issues raised in this matter was: who is going to stand up and defend the employees of the department who have been attacked by Senator Newman in her answer? That is the answer we originally were taking note of. They were in fact attacked and convicted publicly, under privilege. There is no-one, apparently, able to put their case and it is left to the Labor Party to put the case again on behalf of the employees, who are under the direction of the minister. That is a very important point that has to be taken note of.

PARA.BREAK: In relation to the question of the allegations unproven, they seem to change from one day to the next: are there stuff-ups by the people who are doing the work or are there problems because of the management of the job? The allegation seems to have changed from one day to the next, and the Hansard will reveal that. We are again left in the position of dealing with a non-answer by the minister, who seems to have taken as a joke the ques tion of looking after and representing the interests of the employees of the department, whose only proper voice here would be the minister. But, again, it is going to be left to the Labor Party to represent those interests.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to some of the comments that have arisen in this debate and earlier in the statements that have been made, I do not want to talk about the costs of the refurbishment of additional office space and the furnishings because other people will be more competent to deal with those matters. But I do say that it has been made very clear in the statement by Senator Murphy that there is no addition to the cost caused by alleged stuff‐ups.

I challenge the minister to establish that there have been additional costs to the contracted price of the fit‐out. I challenge her to produce that information and evidence or to stand up and apologise to the Senate and to the people against whom those accusations have been made. If the minister cannot prove it, if she cannot establish that there were additional costs as against the original contracted price, then I believe the minister is obliged to apologise.

In relation to that, there is a code of conduct which quite properly was referred to by Senator Murphy. That code of conduct imposes obligations on the minister. If this minister is not prepared to live up to that code, then the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has no choice but to sack her.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really is sad, isn't it, that when we have all these issues facing us as a nation today, such as unemployment, the huge debt, the budget deficit that was left to us by Labor, all that they can do is try to drag up an issue about senators' offices.
—Do you remember Senator Baume and Kirribilli House and dog kennels at the Lodge?

—Senator Collins starts interjecting. Taking up the Keeping up appearances analogies a bit further, you really would make a good Onslow, wouldn't you, Senator Collins? As for Senator Mackay, she would undoubtedly be Daisy or Rose.

BREAK.PARA: What are we talking about? We are talking about the fit-out of a ministerial office that required the carpet to be lifted on three occasions because the situation was not properly managed. I would have thought anybody in the national parliament would say that is something that is to be regretted. The department ought to ensure that it does not occur again and let us move on with the real business of this country. Those opposite have learnt nothing about what the aspirations of the Australian people are. They are not to find out how much Senator Newman spent on refurbishing her office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it?

—Senator Collins interjects, `Isn't it?' Senator Murphy spent $75,000 on a fit‐out as a backbencher. If we have a look at the annual rents, Duncan Kerr spends $76,000 on annual rent compared with my very modest $32,400. If we want to play this game of comparisons, we know who the big spenders are. We know who are the ones who have their snout in the public trough—those sitting opposite. They were the ones who spent up big on their travel allowances. Senator Sherry would have to be a classic example in relation to that.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party is so devoid of issues to run with they are having a crisis of confidence within their own ranks. We have even had the embarrassing performance of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) trying to call a quorum when a quorum was present. He cannot even get those basic numbers right leading the opposition, let alone, for some reason he would have us believe, getting the numbers right when it comes to the question of office fit-outs, rentals and matters of that nature.

Clearly, those on the opposite side have been the big spenders, the wasters of public money. In the past those sorts of things that occurred in Senator Newman's office went without question, were just accepted as part and parcel of government. We have come into government on a policy of getting rid of those sorts of things. We are going to make sure that the taxpayers' money is spent wisely and that those sorts of muck‐ups that occur will not be accepted by this government. If there are people in the administration of government that make mistakes, instead of covering them up we will be saying to them, `Fix them up.'

Let the people of Australia be reminded of one thing: who brought up this issue? It was Labor Senator Kay Denman who raised the issue in question time yesterday. She brought it to the attention of the Australian people and it is backfiring on the Labor Party because the people of Australia now have on the public record the sort of extravagance and incompetence that the previous administration was prepared to put up with. We make no apology for saying that we will not put up with that sort of administration. We are going to clean up the act, and the people of Australia are going to thank us for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator O'Brien very clearly put it on the record with regard to the minister responsible for the work force. The minister approves the budgets for office fit-outs. Senator Newman made a claim that the cost associated with the fit‐out of the extension of her office was associated with so-called stuff‐ups. That is the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: You falsely made accusations against workers and against officers of a department. That is the issue at question here—as to whether or not a senator and a minister can come into this place and blatantly lay down claims, false claims, against people either from a department or from the private sector and get away with it because of the privileged protection she has in this place.

That is the question that must be answered. If the minister has any integrity at all, if she cannot prove the claims that she has made—and she cannot—then the minister should withdraw and should apologise to the people that she has made the claims against. She says no, she will not. She does not say that the claims are wrong. She says no, she will not withdraw, and no, she will not apologise, even though those claims are false.

That is the question. That is the reason this issue was raised. People have a right to protection. They have a right to have their integrity defended if it has been wrongly claimed that they have done something that they have not done. That is the question. Clearly, the minister has a responsibility and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) also has a responsibility to say to the minister, if the minister has made false claims, which she has, that the minister ought to apologise and withdraw them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from the Leader of the Government in the Senate seeking to vary the membership of a standing committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senator Tambling be discharged from the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave for the Senate to debate a motion in similar terms to that which is being debated in the House of Representatives on the issue of race.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This is a form of a motion which had been agreed between the government and the opposition which was to be debated and, no doubt, carried in the House of Representatives. The government is of the view that it should be similarly carried in this place. The terms of the motion are as follows. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate:
(a) reaffirms:

PARA.TAB: (i) its commitment to the right of all Australians to enjoy equal rights and be treated with equal respect regardless of race, colour, creed or origin;
(ii) its commitment to maintaining an immigration policy wholly non‐discriminatory on grounds of race, colour, creed or origin;
(iii) its commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage; and
(iv) its commitment to maintaining Australia as a culturally diverse, tolerant and open society, united by an overriding commitment to our nation, and its democratic institutions and values; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) denounces racial intolerance in any form as incompatible with the kind of society we are and want to Letbe.

I guess in some ways we would say that what we put down in the terms of this motion is really self-evident and, perhaps, should not require reaffirmation in this form. Nevertheless, there does seem to be a debate taking place in the community, and it is important that those of us who have the privilege to lead through this institution do reaffirm these values which are so basic to our society and really help make it the society of which we are so proud. The government has made its position clear time and time again. There is no doubt about that. That should not need to be restated.

But I am prepared to do that again. In particular, I might pick up the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). I refer to a very good speech the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) made to the Malaysia‐Australia alumni conference in Kuala Lumpur on 19 October. Mr Downer quoted what the Prime Minister said in parliament on 8 October. Mr Downer said:
Australia's immigration policy is and will remain non‐discriminatory.

The Government completely rejects any notion that the immigration program should have any reference to race. I personally, and the Government as a whole, find any such notion to be repugnant. Australians in general regard such sentiments as repugnant and we reject them in their entirety.
The fact is that Australia has a proud record for welcoming migrants from all around the world and we will not let that achievement be threatened.
Moreover, Australia's commitment to a non-discriminatory immigration program and to engagement with Asia is bipartisan and enjoys widespread support.
Indeed, our record on immigration has been and remains vital in developing Australia's international links—particularly with our region.

I want to make it absolutely clear that the Australian Government is resolutely opposed to racist sentiment and will fight against it in all its manifestations. That statement is clear, absolute and unequivocal.
I have no doubt that it is a statement that is supported on all sides and by all senators in this place.

I believe we are a tolerant society. We have had a remarkably successful migration program. It has brought immigrants to this country from all over the world—immigrants of all races and so many cultures. We have had a remarkably successful program for receiving refugees. Refugees have come to this country over the decades in waves and, in terms of this debate, we particularly think of how successful the Indochinese refugee program has been.

The result of all this is, I believe, a very healthy multiracial and multicultural society. Part of the culture of Australia in fact is to accept the culture of our immigrants, and we do not ask them to forgo that. We believe that it enriches our society. It becomes part of the broader Australian culture with which we are all happy to be identified.

However, having said that, it is important that we do not take for granted what I have been stating—that is, we are a tolerant society and a multicultural society. It is necessary, it seems, to continue to express it and reaffirm it from time to time—in other words, to not take it for granted. Perhaps what is more important than what we say is what we do. It is important that we practise it, that we demonstrate in our activities within our communities that these values are in fact important to us.

Part of this debate has now broadened into our place within the region and how the multicultural and multiracial society we have developed fits within the region. Again, it is my assessment that it actually fits very comfortably in that Australia's place within the Asia-Pacific region is growing stronger and, in a way, more natural by the day.

I was in Indonesia late last week. I have not been there for some years and I found it fascinating that Australians from every walk of life are now working in Indonesia and are part of their society as well as ours. There are now 10,000 Australians living and working in Indonesia, taking every skill and experience that we have in our country into Indonesia.

Some 300,000 Australians visit Indonesia each year, and the largest percentage growth of tourists to Australia at the moment is coming from Indonesia. It is a demonstration of how we are starting to mesh within the region much more comfortably than we have in the past. Whilst we do not seek to qualify our values or our background, in doing so we recognise that the cultures and backgrounds we are moving into are different and we have to learn to accommodate each other's beliefs.

Far from what some people are attempting to assert in the press and outside this place—that is, it is a difficult task for Australia—my observation is that we are being well received within the region. From an Australian perspective, we are very comfortable with it. The strength of those new relationships will grow as the years go by and will further enhance us not only economically—that is, materially—but also in other ways as we better understand the languages, cultures, histories and values of our neighbours.

So I, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate, take the opportunity to reiterate the values that are contained within this motion. I might have thought that they should not be necessary to restate, but I accept that they are. I trust the Senate will join with us and support us in this motion so no doubt can be left within the community as a whole that this motion identifies the Australia that is important to us and the Australia we wish to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion—more importantly, the debate on this motion—is one of the most significant developments that will take place in this parliament. This motion is significant because, if it is carried, it means the national parliament will insist that an absolutely essential ingredient take its place in the current community discussion about racism and multiculturalism. That ingredient is leadership by us at the national level.

SPEECH.PARA: Without that ingredient, the discussion will continue down ugly and destructive paths. Without the national leadership given to discussions on these issues by governments from both sides of the political divide for the last 30 years, we would never have grown into the tolerant, fair, decent and fundamentally democratic society that we are today.

Since World War II, we have received a massive influx of new citizens bringing with them a wide range of cultures. Over this period, we have progressed from what used to be an inward looking mono‐cultural society. Each new intake of people brought with it a new culture that enriched and sustained our community. We have now become a society in which all these different cultures are not only accommodated but also celebrated.

Over this same period, our attitudes to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have changed. It cannot be said that we have completely and successfully discharged the responsibility given government by the 1967 referendum, but much has been achieved to give Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people their honoured place in the development of Australia as a decent nation.

It has been 30 years since the coalition parties, followed—we freely admit—by the Labor Party, wiped their platform clean of the phrase `white Australia'. It has been more than 20 years since the concept of a white Australia was abolished from official government policy. It has been 20 years since the Fraser government enacted the Northern Territory land rights legislation creating a development which led to the Mabo legislation of the Keating government.

It is more than 20 years since the Whitlam government embraced the concept of multiculturalism. The significance of this was that it finally denied the implication in assimilation and integration that all other cultures, whether indigenous or from overseas, were in some way inferior to the Anglo-Celtic European model.

I mention these changes with pride as an Australian. They have been critical to our becoming a decent society. They are critical for our future. They have been critical also for our relationship with the region around us. This has happened just in time. Having been shut out of our traditional markets, we have to strike out in this region. This has meant our exchanging a tradition‐bound Anglocentricity for a role as a truly multicultural community interacting with our region.

Along the way, we have developed into a decent, hospitable society with a honoured place in the global community through such policies as support for the elimination of institutional racism in South Africa. We in the Labor Party are quick to recognise the role that was played in this by former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. These changes have been critical to the solidity and strength of our relationship with the rest of our region. We have grown into the sort of society with which our neighbours are happy to be associated, with which they are happy to trade.

Of course, we have to be realistic. One of the reasons why we are a decent society is that we are a pluralistic society. Not everybody agrees with the path we have taken—and those who disagree have the right to air their views about it. But when those views are as false and as destructive as some which have been put about lately, they have to be answered. However great the disagreement, we have to preserve our climate of tolerance.

When people are abused in public places, it is time for government, for people in authority, to step in and act—and this is what we need now. It is a disgrace that, because of the way in which the issues of race and multiculturalism have been argued lately, Australian citizens could be physically abused in the street because of their perceived origins. We are especially saddened when we see reports of headlines about this in newspapers in countries all around us, especially newspapers which reflect official or at least authoritative opinion. We have not seen a picture of an Australia like this since the bad old days of white Australia and our discriminatory immigration procedures.

Let me just quote a few of these reports. On October 7, when the member for Oxley put the debate on a new plane, the Bangkok Post talked of `Australia's new found freedom of speech and bigotry'. The South China Morning Post talked of our response `as a stamp of approval for those individuals who hold extremist views to take the stage in Australia'. An official of the Hong Kong Chamber of Commerce thought that the debate would make many local people think twice before travelling to Australia. `It would not take much in Hong Kong,' he said, `to revive memories of the dark days of the White Australia Policy.' A prominent scholar of the School of Commerce at Kayo University in Japan also thought that the debate, as it was developing, `evoked memories of the White Australia Policy'.

As we have seen this week, this view continues among commentators in countries in our region. The Bangkok Post, for example, has commented on our prolonged silence on the issues being debated. Not only is this deeply shaming to us as Australians; it is deeply threatening to us as part of the regional economy. The Nation newspaper of Thailand has warned of potential economic retaliation against Australia. The Australian Tourism Commission has complained that derogatory comments about Asian immigration made during the debate have had a negative impact on tourism into Australia. John Hutchison, managing director of the commission, confirmed this last week in hearings before an estimates committee.

Only a few days ago the Premier of Queensland warned that, as a consequence of the race debate running off the rails, a $12 million investment by Chinese interests in a resort near Brisbane is now in doubt. In Mr Borbidge's own words, the stated reason to a senior member of the government is the `perceived anti-Asian mood in Australia today' and `they are off to New Zealand'.

Finally, just in the last 24 hours, we have had reports that defence personnel from Singapore, guests of Australia, have been attacked and abused in Queensland. It is small wonder that former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser has had to point out to the present Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that the discussion has now got to a point where, in his words, it is `extraordinarily dangerous for the future of Australia'.

The changes that we have seen over the past 20 to 30 years have made Australia a good and decent place to live. They were successful because they have received consistent bipartisan support. They have been sustained because they were supported by the national leadership of the day. In the Labor Party, we are proud of the indigenous and the multicultural policies and activities that have been set in train by Labor leaders such as Gough Whitlam, Bob Hawke and Paul Keating.

I also put on the public record our appreciation of the pioneering roles in all these issues provided by Harold Holt, Malcolm Fraser and state leaders such as Jeff Kennett and Nick Greiner. It was the extent of this bipartisan support and leadership at the national level which helped the community deal sensibly and maturely with the debate that was stimulated when migration issues were raised during the 1980s. By this, I mean the questions raised by Geoffrey Blainey, Lauchlan Chipman, Stephen Rimmer and others—they are good examples—and by the then Leader of the Opposition's One Australia speech at Esperance in 1988 and by the FitzGerald report in the same year.

The question of whether or not the discussion will be as sensible and productive now depends on the line that we take here in the national parliament. This is the central point made by any number of involved observers of the way the race debate has developed—the clerics, the academics, the community organisations. More than any other players in the process, governments have the obligation to make sure that discussion on issues such as race proceed in a proper framework, are not fuelled by falsehood and are not allowed to lead to antisocial consequences.

Keeping the current discussion on race on a sensible and accurate basis, as I have said, is an issue of economic security for us. But the implications of the race issue are much more important than that. Governments have the obligation to point out that it is not true that society has been diminished or threatened by the reconciliation and non-discrimination policies of administrations of all colours over the past 20 years. It is not true that they have subverted our traditional dream of the egalitarian democracy. In fact, they have strengthened this society. Our traditional notions of democracy have survived all the changes that have taken place over the past 20 years. They still accurately describe our dominant values. They transcend ethnicity and race.

Australians are one people and we are many. But we all share faith in Australia and concern for its future and its security. With very few exceptions, we understand this in the national parliament. We have a duty to reassure the community at large about it and not take advantage of it for whatever reason. We cannot let go without challenge the myths and the neuroses that have been let loose in the current discussion about race. We cannot tolerate this as we approach the centenary of our federation. Future generations would never forgive us.

I am confident that this parliamentary debate and the carriage of this motion, late as these actions are, will help us in this parliament to discharge our obligations. On behalf of the opposition, I commend this motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this motion. I want to spend some time talking about why this motion is necessary. It is absolutely necessary because of the deep hurt and offence that has been given to many decent Australians who are simply going about their business of living and making their own contribution to this nation—indigenous Australians, Australians who were born overseas, their children who were born here.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is necessary because of the way that this debate has been absolutely spiralling out of control, because of the damage being done to Australia's reputation as a tolerant multicultural nation, because of the consequent effects on trade, investment, tourism and our capacity to attract overseas students.

This motion is necessary because of the delay that we have seen in this country showing the required leadership on this issue. Mr Malcolm McGregor in today's Financial Review describes it as a `shameful silence'. It is a silence that has resulted in newspaper pages day after day being filled with letters of barely repressed bigotry and hatred, and television news giving—again, evening after evening—great prominence to bigoted, ignorant and offensive views.
