The problem is that those views go unchallenged. Equal time has not been given to the other side of the issue.

It is a shameful silence that has resulted in letters, in this case from Chinese students, from Deakin University, La Trobe University, Melbourne University, Monash University, RMIT, et cetera, saying:

We are Chinese international students . . . studying in Australian universities . . . Unfortunately, we have been targeted by racial hatred and are suffering of racial hostility directed against us. The cases of . . . insults/attacks on our members, our families, and even on our children are increasing daily; some of us have been attacked by the racists at the railway stations, in the streets, on the roads, at the shopping centres, even at the schools and university campuses for no reasons.
This is Australia in 1996. It is a shameful silence that has resulted in the Vietnamese Australia Welfare Association of New South Wales, in its newsletter for this month, recording:
. . . the . . . Vietnamese Community in Australia have recently received bomb threats and this has made people question to what length freedom of speech should be allowed to go.

It is a shameful silence which invites others to perpetrate fraud. A respected former member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, Mr Ted Egan, found, one Saturday morning, that somebody had written a letter in his name, expressing views quite the opposite of what he holds about future prospects for reconciliation and healing. Mr Egan had to have a letter published disassociating himself from that letter.

It is a shameful silence which sees my 13½‐year‐old daughter, with her close Asian friends of the last seven years, simply walking down the streets in Brisbane and being told, `Go back where you came from!'—something she has never experienced in her 13½ years of life. It is something which causes her distress and anguish and obviously to question why this is happening. It is, as others have referred to it, a silence that has seen visiting Asian troops subjected to insults and violence; a silence which has seen attacks on indigenous Australians, which has resulted in distortions of their place in history—in fact, almost a denial of their place in history.

In contrast to the silence, we have seen in this place the continued imputations directed towards indigenous Australians—of a lack of accountability, of fraud, of corruption, of incompetence—day after day after day. It has been very hard to have the other side of that story told as well. This motion is absolutely necessary because previous qualified silences have resulted in an incitement to vilification, a lack of respect—a hatred almost—all dressed up under the guise of free speech.

In the last 50 days, since that disgraceful speech, some Australians have spoken out. I know Democrats have spoken out. I am reminded that, in 1977, the Democrats were founded on the slogan of tolerance, honesty and compassion. Some people thought that was very idealistic and old-fashioned, but I think they are qualities that are very important in Australia in 1996.

It is important for leaders not to wait to sniff the wind of public opinion before they speak, because some truths are fundamental. One of those that I truly believe is that evil flourishes where good men and women sit and do nothing.

Let me address what the motion says. There is not much in it to quibble about. I find it very interesting that it avoids the use of the word `multiculturalism' and uses the words `cultural diversity'. That change is interesting to me. Of course I support reaffirmation of our support for the reconciliation process. Of course I support the sentiments associated with cultural diversity in this motion. But what is interesting to me are the omissions.

I compared the words with the words of the original motion, which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) tabled some time ago, and that original motion certainly uses the word `multiculturalism', and it certainly talks about providing leadership. There is no mention of history in this motion. I find that incredibly disappointing and cowardly, because how are we going to stand up as a mature nation—Senator Hill talked about going towards the next century—without simply acknowledging our past, without acknowledging the fact that there have been failures of policy in the past?

We can do that without saying we have to acknowledge guilt. We can talk about the shame some may feel, but we have to acknowledge in order to heal and move on. So this motion is incredibly deficient in that respect. I listened to the speech in the other place by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in support of this motion and I note that he still asserts that we are too apologetic about our history and far too self-conscious about our achievements. How ironic that many countries in the world consider our success in multiculturalism to be one of our achievements—but we are not allowed to talk about our past.

I think leadership is incredibly important. Leadership sets the tone of this country. It defines what we are and what we aspire to be. Leadership leads to understanding, and I think there has been a failure of leadership in one important area, which has led to the capacity to exploit people's fears about difference. I think that failure of leadership has been on the pace of change in this country as a result of the economic rationalist policies of the last decade or so, a simple failure to say, `Of course we are living in an era of global capitalism; of course there are adjustments this country has to make; yes, there will be some pain on transition; yes, we are planning to ease the pain of transition.' We have had none of this.

That is why I accept that people feel insecure about the future. But that does not mean that they are excused for taking refuge in ignorance and racism. It is absolutely time for leadership on this issue. It is time to restore respect for the dignity of our fellow Australians. It is time to restore mutual respect, because that is what tolerance is based on. Mutual respect is the fundamental prerequisite of reconciliation, and it is that respect that has been missing in this debate for the last 50 days or so.

No-one in this country should be afraid of a rigorous debate about immigration levels and population policy. No-one should be afraid about rigorous debate on what constitutes appropriate policy directions in indigenous affairs, but it has to be a debate without hate. I have been ashamed of the debate in this country over the past 50 days. I do not want to live in a country that is perceived as racist by Australians who live here and by our important neighbours overseas.

Mr Howard may say he abhors racism and he may hope that this motion proves that, but it is my view and the Democrats' view that it will take more than a resolution of a couple of hundred parliamentarians to redress the deep hurt and offence that has been caused to so many Australians. It will take more than this motion to redress the damage that has been created by 50 days of qualified shameful silence. Make no mistake about it—the damage that has been done is long term and it is deep. The healing that we were hoping would happen as we move into the next century has irreparably been set back.

The Democrats support this motion, but they support it with the qualifications that I have made in my comments this afternoon. It is very disappointing to me that we have omitted some important facets—the reality of history and the acknowledgment of what leadership can do in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, I wish to associate myself with this motion in the strongest possible terms. It is a sad day when the Australian parliament finds itself in the position of having to reaffirm fundamental beliefs about the society which we are all working towards no matter what our political perspectives are.

SPEECH.PARA: Last weekend, the Queensland National Party approved an ethnic affairs policy which has as its opening statement:

BREAK.PARA: The strength of Australia is a result of its people from different backgrounds working as one Australian society with diverse cultures.
The National Party recognises the contribution migrants have made and that it will continue to form the basis for the development of our Australian society.
The policy continues:
The National Party will continue to work for greater tolerance, understanding and equality towards all Australians and their culture.

The National Party policy is inconsistent with the comments made by the independent member for Oxley, Ms Pauline Hanson. I do not believe I can beat around the bush with this. It has to be said and it has to be said straight out.

I have often gone on the record in this place to warn about the dangers of snake oil salespeople selling simplistic solutions to complex problems. Australia seems to throw up these glitches from time to time. First there was Eric Butler and then there was Jeremy Lee, Peter Sawyer and Graeme Campbell.

The appeal of political charlatans is not to be ignored. It is real. It will always be there in a dark corner of Australian psyche, but we are not the elders of the village of Hameln that let the Pied Piper come in and take away our children. The motion before us means that we can strengthen our opposition to intolerance, that we are on guard about the threats to it and that we regard non‐discrimination as an essential part of our society to be defended at all costs.

Like others before her, Ms Hanson is an exploiter of fears and prejudices. She exploits unhappiness, frustration and cynicism. She capitalises all those who feel the trauma of rapid economic and social change. I have heard her been spoken of well by professionals and by academics. We are not just talking about those people actually referred to as rednecks.

The Hanson phenomena has been compared to many things, but to me it is a disturbing echo of the Lindy Chamberlain saga, where otherwise rational people, community leaders and so on fell in with this lynch mob mentality. This sort of hysteria takes on a life of its own and can turn the world upside down. Why should Lindy Chamberlain be deemed guilty while Pauline Hanson is treated like the virgin Joan of Arc?

Like the gun debate before it, the Hanson factor has the potential to accumulate a political head of steam. A recent Morgan poll published in the Bulletin this week showed that a Hanson-led party would win 18 per cent of the Senate vote if there were an election now. I would like to speculate on what that hypothetical situation would mean to the Senate. We all know that opinion polls are volatile and have limited application. I do not think for a moment that that would happen, but let us just assume that we have just had an election and the Hanson party has won 18 per cent of the vote and now has the balance of power in the Senate.

What signals would this send not only to Australians but to the rest of the world? How would the Senate operate as a result? The government would introduce legislation. What would be the price for winning Hanson party support to allow the legislation to pass? What deals would be offered? Would the Hanson party demand substantial and discriminatory cuts in immigration and foreign aid? Would compulsory national service be the price for letting government legislation through? Would Australian children once more be threatened with removal from their mothers if they did not win the Hanson tidy town competition?

If the government would not bargain or negotiate, what then? Political instability and further elections? Imagine the strains the Hanson party would put on the operation of the Senate. Would we have MPIs on Australia being swamped by Asians or references to committees about international financiers conspiring to run the world?

PARA.BREAK: In order to mobilise the Hanson supporters, whose networks and organisations support will be used? Who will be called on to develop her anecdotes into policy documents? Already we have seen Ms Hanson collecting well‐wishers like Bruce Whiteside and the One Australia Movement born out of the scattered CAP ranks. Did the 500 people who allegedly signed up to this fan club know that they were each paying $5 to a group associat ed with extreme right‐wingers, some of whom even deny the Jewish holocaust?

BREAK.PARA: Who will run the Hanson movement? Who will offer the networks, administration and advice? The same group who thought Graeme Campbell was their great white hope—only now they have an even whiter champion. Racial intolerance is incompatible with the kind of society we are and want to be, as the motion before us says today. We cannot have any reverence for our own lives without reverence for others. The respect is missing from Ms Hanson's demeanour.

Three years ago in the Australian a letter to the editor from a Chinese immigrant was published. It had the headline `You gave me so much—I'll repay the debt'. After working to support himself, this man became ill and had a lifesaving operation. These are his words:
The medical report show that I was given 8 litre blood while I had 14 hours' brain operation. So now Australian people's blood are flowing through my whole body. It is Australia saving my life.
While this country give me something, I must give something back. . . I do thank you, Australia, who give me the opportunity of regeneration. God bless Australia.

Surely this is the attitude we want to encourage, both here and abroad. The increasing international reports and today's Daily Telegraph Mirror headline about Asian soldiers being abused in this country are not.

As Australians we have a choice at this point. Are we the country of regeneration or degeneration? It may well end up as a choice between having Senator O'Chee in this chamber or a Pauline Hanson clone or worse, depending on who she aligns herself with. Anyone who heard Senator O'Chee's speech earlier today would realise the great contrast between an Australian who brings a legacy of tolerance, freedom and respect for all Australians and the narrow, bigoted and wilful ignorance of the likes of Ms Hanson. If Australians make the Morgan poll a reality at the next election, then they say to people like Bill O'Chee, `Your childhood fears of being vilified in the school playground were only a vision of what is to come.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Greens join earlier speakers in totally deploring the turn of events in this country since Pauline Hanson made her inaugural speech in the House of Representatives. It was a sheer coincidence that, at the very same time she was making that speech, I was making a speech in this house reflecting Greens policy for an egalitarian country where everybody, without fear or favour, felt proud to be able to demonstrate their own feelings, their own culture, their own creed and their own zest for life. It was a call to this country, this lucky nation of ours, to take a lead in a world where we are no longer apart, but part of a global village of six billion people. If we cannot do it in this country with the inherent advantages we have, then we cannot expect people elsewhere to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: I like to think that it was a good thing that that speech I gave got no coverage in the Australian press, but the next day headlines everywhere covered the racist epithets in particular from Pauline Hanson. What I was saying reflected more clearly and closely the real feeling of Australians, and what she was articulating was the absurd, abhorrent and anti‐Australian viewpoint. However, things have proceeded in a downward spiral on the slippery slope towards a more divided Australia and, as a consequence of this debate on racism in this country, an Australia with its reputation impugned. There is little evidence to say that we are off that slippery slope.

To me, there is still a simple factor in this—the touch point to this unseemly debate that has taken up Australia—and that is Pauline Hanson herself: Pauline Hanson, the member of the House of Representatives, who knowingly took her first opportunity to exhibit this unseemly discourse on racism and bigotry which is now a matter for universal comment, not only in this country but increasingly elsewhere around the world, to our detriment.

While I support this motion wholeheartedly, I still believe it pulls the punch. It still fails to take the confrontation for those of us who feel appalled by Pauline Hanson's philosophy to that member of the House of Representatives. Moreover, it fails to come to grips with the reality that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself has failed to take her head‐on. He has gone out of his way to avoid naming her as the spark in this conflagration against our nation's interests. I do not believe it will be until he, as the leader of this nation, as head of government, joins all of us in condemning her that we will start to put things back to rights.

I think that the Prime Minister has made a mistake in believing that, by ignoring her, in some way or other she will go away. In fact, what has happened, sadly, is that her notoriety is inversely proportional to his recognition of her central role in what is happening. It is essential that he take her on as an individual who must take major responsibility for this awful debate that is taking place in this wonderful nation of ours. Therefore, I move an amendment to this motion in the following terms:
After paragraph (b), add:
(c) Deplores the racist statements of the Member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and calls on the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to name her and condemn her bigotry.

I do so because I believe, otherwise, we too are pulling the punch and we are not going to the core of the problem. Until we do, we are not going to be able to face the problem, dampen it down and apply the medicine that is required. The newspaper comments which increasingly say that the Prime Minister has failed or has made a mistake in his decision not to take on Pauline Hanson are correct. I believe that this motion falls short in that it does not do so either. Pauline Hanson ought to be taken to account in this motion. The Prime Minister's failure to recognise her central role in this, and his repeated refusals to do so, even under fairly intense inducement from journalists in this country, has been a mistaken policy.

I do not believe it is going to give her greater kudos or add anything to her bailiwick. I think it is going to add a united front to the leadership against this insidious racism which has come into public discourse in Australia. It is important that we have the courage to inveigle the Prime Minister to change tack and let Pauline Hanson know that we hold her responsible—along with, of course, those who are speaking out in her support—for the hurt and the harm to so many individuals in our nation and to the nation as a whole as far as our international reputation is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —As Australians, we are all privileged to live in one of the freest, fairest and most tolerant societies on earth. It has not always been that way, but it is now. As I said in the adjournment debate last night, it is not the absolutely indisputable fact about our racist and bigoted past that worries me, and I am worried; it is the prospect, because of the complete lack of leadership that has been demonstrated on this issue, of a racist and bigoted future that concerns me greatly.

SPEECH.PARA: I got a phone call early this morning from a close, journalist friend of mine, an American. She has been in Australia for more than 20 years. Last night she had a sleepless night about this and rang me in the early hours of this morning to say, `I've lived in this country for 20 years and have never seen anything like the last two months since I've been here. I'm absolutely terrified that, if something sensible and reasonable is not done to keep this in check, then this country is going to degenerate into the same sort of social division that exists in my former home of the United States.'

She is entitled to have that fear—I think we all are. Is it reasonable to suggest for a minute that the sort of situation we are, without question, faced with at the moment could all have been caused by a backbencher, a single member of the federal parliament in the House of Representatives? Of course that is nonsense. It couldn't have been. Are the apprehensions of the international press that are now coming forward based on some misconception or misunderstanding, as the Prime Minister would have, about the situation here in Australia? I do not believe they are. In fact, I believe I can demonstrate very quickly that they are not.

It is not Pauline Hanson, I regret to say, who has brought this about. It is not Pauline Hanson who is responsible in a real sense for the appalling situation where members of the military forces from Singapore have been attacked openly on our streets, one being elbowed in the face, another having eggs thrown at her and being subject to verbal abuse. It is not Pauline Hanson who is responsible for an elected mayor of an Australian city publicly expressing the view, `My three beautiful kids are mongrels.' Pauline Hanson does not have this power. She does not possess it. I regret to say, the reason—and it finally has to be appreciated—we are in this very unpleasant situation as a nation at the moment is that the person who speaks on these issues for us all, irrespective of our political allegiances, the Prime Minister, has shown a profound lack of leadership.

As a politician, I recognise what he has been doing and he has to be brought to account for it. The Leader of the Government in the Senate said two things which I noted: one I agreed with and one I did not. Senator Hill said that we should not require the reaffirmation of the sentiments that are contained in this motion. He is right; we shouldn't. What we need to examine, as Senator Kernot noted, is the reason why we are doing it. The reason we are doing it is that the Prime Minister's crimes of omission but, more particularly, commission, need to be noted in this respect. The thing Senator Hill said that I did not agree with was:
Perhaps what is more important than what we say is what we do.

The one thing that distinguishes the human species from other species on this earth is our ability to communicate in a very sophisticated form of language. We as politicians know full well that what we say has always been as important as what we do, and it is now. That really is what has brought us to this particular point that we are at now.

Over the last two months an impression has been deliberately created that the sentiments expressed by Pauline Hanson, as sad, wrong, ill-informed and ignorant as they are, have had the silent support of the Prime Minister of Australia. That is an appalling position for us all to be in.

This is an issue which has dominated debate in this country like none other this year. It is an issue that strikes at the absolute heart of the Australian ethos as we want to see it and Australia's place in the world. In that forum, who is the person, irrespective of our political affiliations, who speaks for us all collectively? It is the Prime Minister of Australia. The Prime Minister of Australia has dodged and weaved and ducked on this issue every time the name Pauline Hanson has been mentioned. You cannot get better evidence for that—I commend all honourable senators to have a look at it—than the transcript of the interview that he did with John Laws on 24 October. Read it; it is instructive. I do not agree with everything that John Laws believes in or says, but I commend John Laws on this occasion for the assiduous way that he tried to pin our Prime Minister down on this matter. Read the transcript. On page 1 John Laws asks:
. . . you were hearing what Australians were saying in light of what was said by Pauline Hanson?
The Prime Minister replies:
. . . what are you getting at?
As if he did not know! John Laws went on. Page 2 of the transcript says:
But when that speech causes concern in the country . . .

A full paragraph of gobbledegook follows from the Prime Minister, not wanting to directly answer the question. If we keep going over to page 3 of the transcript, John Laws interrupts the flow and says:
Just tell me this . . .
When he did not succeed, the Prime Minister went on to say:
Well, could I just finish saying one thing John, we will never go back in this country to having a discriminatory immigration policy based on race.
John Laws persists on page 4 of the transcript, still trying to pin down the Prime Minister. He says to him:
But aren't we entitled to know how you would react when . . .
The Prime Minister said:
No, you are entitled to know what I believe in.
John Laws says:
But aren't we entitled to know what you believe then when you hear . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —When you hear what?
—Exactly. This is Pauline Hanson's sentiments about race, Senator Harradine. John Laws goes on and asks this question:

SPEECH.PARA: But aren't we entitled to know what your attitude is to certain things? For example, in Dubai the Khalese Times editorial is headed, "Shrill Voice of Racism Holds Centre Stage in Australia." Now, aren't we entitled to know how you'd react to that?
The Prime Minister said:
I react to that in the same way that I react to some newspaper editorials in Australia. I don't take any notice of it.
This is after four pages of trying to pin down the Prime Minister on simply saying whether he, to quote John Laws, `Accepts or rejects what she says'. He said:
But is it good for Australia?
The Prime Minister goes on for another page. We then get to page 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does he say?

—I do not have time to read it all out, Senator Harradine. That is why I suggested to you that you read it. The full transcript of the Laws interview of 24 October is available on the parliamentary database. Finally, on page 6 John Laws gives up and says:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, I think we'd better talk about other issues.

He could not pin the Prime Minister down with a forthright statement about what he believed. But I talked about the Prime Minister's sins of commission, not omission, that have led to the situation that we are in.

Have a look at the front page of today's Sydney Morning Herald, with the headline `Howard blasts Asian critics'. That will be worth another five per cent to him at the moment in terms of the people who support Pauline Hanson. `That is telling them where to get off', says the Prime Minister! Above that headline is a smaller heading which says, `PM remains defiant over Hanson as Fischer voices concern on trade.' Other members of this government—I wish to commend them—have been very forthright in their rejection of these views. The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, has been; the Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, has been; and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, has been.

That brings me to what the Prime Minister actually said rather than what he did not say. I believe that what he said was contemptible. It was not racist; it was political. He was trying, as I said in the adjournment debate last night, to do what politicians try to do too often—that is, have two bob each way and keep both sides of the fence happy. He knows what his researcher is telling him—that this stuff has tapped a vein of ignorance.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's ridiculous.

—Just wait and listen to the quote, Senator, because it offended me mightily at the time. The Prime Minister made this very silly statement about a new dawn of free speech that has occurred in Australia since 2 March this year. What nonsense it was. We have always enjoyed in our modern history the right of free speech to an extent that many countries in the world have not.

SPEECH.PARA: This nonsense about political correctness was simply code, particularly for those of us who are in this business of throwing words around and understanding them. It was code for, `Although I am being politically correct in saying the things I need to say, to rebut the things that Pauline Hanson is saying, I nevertheless quietly—wink‐wink, nudge‐nudge—am giving support to them.' He was far more explicit about this. The federal Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, said, `I disagree very strongly with the things Pauline Hanson said.' He was right up front. On the same day he said that, what did the Prime Minister say? He said that a number of the comments made by Ms Hanson were `an accurate reflection of what people feel'.

What people is the Prime Minister of Australia talking about when he makes a statement like that? Did he qualify it by saying `what some people feel' or `what a few people feel'. That would have been bad enough. He did not. On the same day as he talked about everyone having the right to free speech, he said that Pauline Hanson reflected `accurately' what people feel. When that is reported on the front page of Australian newspapers, as it should be, accurately, and then it is picked up overseas, who do you think—reasonably—overseas journalists, opinion makers or politicians believe that the Prime Minister of Australia is talking about when he says the all embracing word `people'? Of course, he is referring to the Australian people—to us. These issues are central to our national ethos and, I might add, to our international place in the world. He is our spokesperson, irrespective of whether he is Labor, Liberal or whatever. He speaks for us all on these subjects.
On the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald this morning the Prime Minister is reported as saying:

Suggestions in some sections of the Asian media that in some way I have encouraged—by what I have said or what I have not said—any acts of discrimination against Asian Australians are absolutely wrong . . .

Can that statement be sustained? No, it cannot, because the Prime Minister's own words rebut it. Pauline Hanson, the member for Oxley, had no further authority than her own. The sentiments she expressed should have simply hung there either unsupported or attacked—which is what they should have been—or corrected, as Dr Wooldridge and Mr Ruddock corrected them, to their credit. On the day that she said them, the Prime Minister said on behalf of us all that, as far as he was concerned, what she had said in its entirety was an accurate reflection of what people feel in Australia.

Therefore, is the impression that has been formed overseas by these journalists or by opinion makers—the people who are writing these stories—inaccurate or accurate? It is accurate: the Prime Minister's own words provide the foundation for it. It was a totally unqualified statement.

Let us have a look at the games that the Prime Minister has been playing with all of us on this. We all have our own biases and prejudices; it is not a prejudice free or bias free world. I come from a city that has had two Chinese Australian lord mayors. The first, Harry Chan, was not only mayor of Darwin but also president of our first parliament; the second, Alec Fong Lim, probably the most successful and popular mayor Darwin has ever had, would probably still be mayor if it had not been for his death.

I come from an Australian city very close to Asia with a long history of Asian involvement going back to the turn of the century. I know that what politicians say is important. The Prime Minister, having declared that we had a new birth of free speech, went on to say a month later that he was very disturbed about school teachers teaching children that we had a racist and bigoted past in Australia. Did he qualify those words? No, he did not. He simply said that Australians are told quite regularly that we have a racist and bigoted past. Well, do we? Yes, we do. Is that something that we should feel guilty about? No, it is not.

The Prime Minister, in debate again yesterday, said that we should not have a `black armband' approach to our history. You need to see all of these statements of the Prime Minister together to understand the impact that they are having. But what did the Prime Minister say today in debate on this motion about a racist and bigoted past? Of course we had that past. We had a White Australia Policy until very recently. It was official government policy that you could not get into this country if you were not white. I am not quite sure how much more racist you can be than that.

We had little things like the Coniston massacre, which, in another place and another time, would have been determined to be a war crime, without any threat or hindrance. As I pointed out in debate last night, next year, 1997, will be the 30th anniversary of the Aboriginal people of Australia becoming citizens in their own country. As I said last night, that is not exactly prehistory or the deep past.

What did the Prime Minister say today in terms of these word games he has been playing for the last two months? He said that he rejected that we have a `totally racist and prejudiced past'. The spin doctors have been at it again overnight, and that is what has been happening over the last two months.

Would it have been a nonsense for anyone to have suggested that we have a totally racist and prejudiced past? Of course it would be nonsense. But that is not what the Prime Minister said up until yesterday. Today the language has changed. It is classic Animal Farm stuff from politics. The message on the blackboard changes every night. There is a new message up for you every morning and John Howard, the Prime Minister of Australia, has done it again.

The thing that he cannot escape from, as I said before, is that while his deputy was forthrightly attacking the comments of the member for Oxley, whilst the minister for health was pointing out the errors—and, I might add, to their credit, other Liberal backbenchers in the House of Representatives in their maiden speeches did so as well—and while the minister for immigration was properly, responsibly and carefully pointing out the facts, that Ms Hanson was wrong about us being swamped by Asian immigration in Australia, the Prime Minister, in the same context, was saying publicly that people—all people, us people, we people, the Australian people—in fact were sympathetic to the sentiments that Ms Hanson was expressing. In fact, he said that it was an accurate reflection of what people—all Australian people—feel. It is not what this person feels.

I resent the fact that the person I acknowledge speaks for me on the international stage on these issues was wrong. He is not speaking for all Australian people when he says that, but he should have been. When he links that to this nonsense about a new dawn of free speech—these statements were all made on the same day—is it unreasonable for people to add two and two together and come up with four, just as he wanted them to?

I have campaigned in political campaigns over the last 20-odd years in a place where race issues are daily bread—the Northern Territory. I have on many occasions been verbally attacked by groups of people in the Northern Territory on the Labor Party's support for land rights for Aboriginal people, for example. At those meetings—this was a regular event—people would get stuck into me and say, `We won't vote for the Labor Party because you are strong supporters of land rights for Aboriginal people.' At those meetings I would produce the Country Liberal Party's written policy and I would say to these people, with the voice of sweet reason, `Yes, we do support these aspirations for Aboriginal people but so, might I point out, do the Country Liberal Party, our political opponents. Here it is in black and white in their policy documents.' The reaction I used to get to that, time and time again, was, `Yes, we know that is in their policy—they have to put that in there—but they don't mean it and the Labor Party does. That is why we will be voting for the CLP.' That is the Realpolitik that the Prime Minister has been trading off for the last two months, but he has been making those trades at the great expense of this country and it is about time it stopped.

I would have a lot more to say about the distortions that have been made of Aboriginal affairs over the last few months, all of which have been strongly and publicly supported by the Prime Minister—the nonsense that investigations into the affairs of Aboriginal organisations have disclosed that 90 per cent of them mismanage their money when in fact the reports cleared 95 per cent of all organisations and gave them a clean bill of health—but I am not going to do that.

What I am going to say is that the concerns that have been raised by the overseas press are, I regret to say, legitimate. The press reports are not ill-informed. They are, in real substance, based on accurate reports from the Australian media of the Prime Minister saying in respect of the remarks that were made by the honourable member for Oxley, which would have fallen, I think, on fairly barren ground if she had not had this support from the Prime Minister, that not only was this a land of free speech and she had the right to say it—no-one is doubting that—but more importantly `what she said was an accurate reflection of what people feel in this country'. Well, it isn't, it wasn't and I hope it won't be. It is about time, on an issue this important to the national interests of our country, the Prime Minister started saying that up front.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite important that the Senate is debating the issues in front of us today, though I feel—it is probably not surprising to people who have listened to the contributions I have made on similar issues in the past—that the majority of the debate has missed the point. I think it is extremely interesting that Mr Beazley's most public response in relation to the issues we are dealing with today has been a concern expressed about the impact these debates and issues might have on Australia's trade figures.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of concern to me—I reflect the statement made by Senator Boswell here—that the issues relate to responses to what Senator Boswell called the trauma of rapid social and economic change. Until we in Australia can admit and deal with the issues related to rapid social and economic change, then statements like we see today may assist but will never deal with the issues that are creating this level of disharmony, distress, hurt and anger in society. There are a number of issues.

I have people calling my office who do not know what to do in terms of their lives and want someone to do something about what they think is the Pauline Hanson factor. They ask: why doesn't someone speak out? I explain to them as best I can that we have a very fertile environment in Australia of people who are disillusioned because there have been massive social and economic changes within the last few years. They have changed people's livelihoods, their lifestyles, the nature of their work and even their family environment. They have changed the way people are able to think about each other and the way communities form and hang together or fall apart.

The `me' generation that comes with economic fundamentalism has hurt a great many people, as has the rapid change associated with competition policy, which basically pits one person against another and assumes that we get better social outcomes. Quite truly, if we were honest enough to look, we would find that those outcomes can be very damaging in our society. But social outcomes are not the real aim of many of these policies. People are being hurt.

That is not excusing anybody from speaking out. However, there is blame to be laid on the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for not saying clearly whether or not he disagreed with a statement made by a member of the House of Representatives. That is very clear. There is a responsibility to respond to those issues. We know that just as issues of trade can be poll driven so can issues of scapegoatism. It is my belief that the Prime Minister did have a responsibility to clearly disagree with those statements but the polls were saying, `If you do that you will lose this growing popularity that comes from riding in on the wave of scapegoatism.'

But just dealing with words and dealing with individuals will not solve any problems in Australia. What will perhaps begin to lead to a change will be for us to acknowledge the history, for instance, of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australia, to attempt to understand and to deal with the real problems that arise from that history. That is important. I agree with Senator Kernot there, but we also need to acknowledge the reality of our recent history.

In New Zealand there has been, if you like, a similar response. The last election saw not just a response for New Zealand First, which was perhaps a physical reminder of how disconcerted people can be with this wave of internationalism when they are starting to talk about what the outcomes are of this link to internationalism—there are a lot of various, mixed and confused ideas in there with New Zealand First—but there was also a rise of the Alliance in New Zealand. The Greens were involved in the Alliance as well. There has been an entire political change.

At least in New Zealand they are now beginning, because of that political change, to talk about some of those issues which have manifested themselves in what appears to be a racially based argument. It is not just occurring in Australia and New Zealand; it is occurring in various parts of the world. I would put it to you that even the in the situations in Rwanda, Zaire and former Yugoslavia there are elements of those pressures of the new wave of internationalism, free trade at all costs, and massive changes, that are boiling into that level of scapegoatism.

We, in Australia, have to be intelligent enough to start addressing the issues and start seeing why it is so easy in 1996 for people's fears to be manipulated in the way they are. Until we start talking about those massive economic and social changes, what part we have all had in creating those, whether those changes were correct, whether those decisions were right and whether there are different things we should be doing, we will continue to have the `lock them up' law and order debate that we have had in Western Australia over the last few years with the former Premier Carmen Lawrence, followed by the `lock them up' election platform of the former leader of the opposition in Western Australia, Jim McGinty, ALP.

This is the answer: social disruption and alienation caused by massive social change and let's point the finger at the victims; let's point the finger at the symptoms of the change; let's not deal with the issues involved with the massive social change that we are experiencing and that a number of countries around the world are equally experiencing. No amount of word games will change this situation enough for us to be able to honestly deal with this situation in Australia.

I mentioned in a previous speech that with the issues of the massive economic and social changes over free trade and structural adjustment there have been riots in various parts of the world. They are seeing immediately what that outcome is and nobody is stopping that debate. I would have to say that the media, which are currently pointing to the Prime Minister saying, `Name her! Name her!', must also bear a large part of the responsibility if they have not fostered proper debate about the issues which have created this degree of social discohesion in Australia.

We must all bear that responsibility and perhaps from this day onwards say that we will not continue to pretend that the leap into internationalism has been the best thing since sliced bread but continue to pretend that people are not hurting because of that. I asked questions the other day of Senator Hill and he gave me the same answer I was getting three years ago: `Yes, we are still going to get billions of dollars of benefits.' It is not here and the people in the street know it is not here. They can see it in their shops. They can see it in their lifestyles. They can see it in their working lives. We are pretending it is not even happening.

It is time for us to be honest and say that this parliament has a responsibility to start talking about these issues. The community has the right to be given information about what those pressures have been and why those changes have occurred. If we are honest enough to start talking about what changes have occurred, we then must be honest enough to say what the options are. If the response from government—and I remember it was very close to the response of Senator McMullan in dealing with the World Trade Organisation bills—is that virtually we have no choice, if that is what is believed by governments and opposition, then let us hear it. Let us debate that we have no choice. I do not believe it. I think there are thousands of choices.

But the real issue, I believe, is that, if we are pretending there is no other choice and, because of that, pretending that what we have done is right and that there are no problems and all we have got to do is buckle down, privatise more, internationalise more and trade ourselves out of existence and everything will be fine, we will continue to have these debates. We will continue to live in a society of which we will become increasingly ashamed. I call on the members of the Senate to start taking their responsibilities—all of their responsibilities—as leaders seriously and start working for change as from today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —There were a number of comments made by the last speaker, Senator Dee Margetts, that we should really consider very thoroughly, but it is not the time to do it now. I have been asked to speak for no more than five minutes on this particular matter.

SPEECH.PARA: But she is correct. Much of the blame goes on the press because they have run with a particular statement of a backbench member of this parliament and blown it out of all proportion and not even attempted to consider the underlying problems of social cohesion that we are experiencing at the present moment, and this includes employment. They are the ones that should at least examine the question of employment. Of course it has nothing to do with the immigration program, except in certain very narrow areas, say, for example, the oversupply of doctors.

Generally, immigration into this country has built this country. Immigration into this country creates jobs overall. There have been a number of studies done on this particular matter. As I have indicated before, there is an enormous problem with jobs, particularly for the young at the present moment. Let us have a look at the reason for that such as policies that require families to have one, two and three incomes to make ends meet. We will get on to that in the objects of the workplace relations legislation, which ought to look at the question of unemployment and the reasons for unemployment and whether they are being overcome by that legislation. I certainly do not think they are. I am certain of it.

There is an underlying racism in some of our foreign policies, for example, the population control policy. There are other major areas that we should be looking at, too, in relation to anti-discrimination. You may have read this morning of the German biochemist who proudly states that he is a cripple. He was a thalidomide baby. He is now 34. He said, `If I was an unborn child now,'—if it happened now—`I would not be able to be born.' Let us just think of what this nation is doing. Let us look at other discrimination—discrimination against the disabled that is taking place and being paid for by this government in the abortion of those unborn children who are deemed not to be perfect. Let us have a look at that. That is never put forward in the press.

I am proud to stand here and acknowledge the contribution that has been made to this nation by immigrants. I do so having married one of them. I do so as the father-in-law of a Javanese girl from Indonesia who is expecting another baby in a week's time or so. I am very proud of my daughter-in-law and all of those other people who have made such a contribution to this country. I am also honoured by the contribution that indigenous Australians have made to this country, particularly those Aboriginal Australians who share the name of Harradine.

BREAK.PARA: I support wholeheartedly this motion, but I raise one issue about it. This motion was moved in the House of Representatives by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and supported by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley. I thought that what we would do here today would be to carry a resolution without highlighting a particular individual who has contributed very little to the debate. Certainly, she has contributed much that passes for debate but she has not contributed anything to a proper, intellectual and informed debate. She has made shallow and intolerant statements that pass for debate.

I personally am opposed to singling out an individual in this particular motion. I believe we should be above that sort of thing. The motion reaffirms our commitment to the rights of all Australians to enjoy equal rights and be treated with equal respect regardless of race, colour, creed or religion. Of course, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights recognises the inherent dignity and the equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family as the foundation of freedom, justice and peace in the world. I feel that what has passed for debate thus far has caused division and distress to a large number of people. Again, I say the media have a lot to answer for.

The motion reaffirms our commitment to maintaining an immigration policy, wholly non‐discriminatory on the grounds of race, colour, creed or origin. It reaffirms our commitment to the process of reconciliation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the context of redressing their profound social and economic disadvantage. We reaffirm our commitment to maintaining Australia as a culturally diverse, tolerant and open society united by an overriding commitment to our nation and our democratic institutions and values. We denounce racial intolerance in any form as incompatible with the kind of society we are—at least I hope we are—and certainly the kind we want to be.
I join with colleagues in the House of Representatives and other colleagues here in supporting this motion. I hope it is carried unanimously in the form that I have just read out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate today is about an unseen guest, and her name is Pauline Hanson. I feel very strongly on this issue for a number of reasons, and I will be supporting the motion. It is a good motion as far as it goes, although one could debate whether or not it goes far enough.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons I feel strongly about this issue is that I am a politician who is in Pauline Hanson's way. Having had some members of the Liberal Party in Queensland speak to me about this issue, that is their assessment of the politics of the whole debate. I am also a Uniting Church minister, and have spent almost all of my life in Queensland confronting this issue for it is one that surfaces in that state regularly. I have tried to promote what I believe is a Christian vision of a tolerant and caring society. I do not believe that you can have a caring or a Christian society if it is not a tolerant one.

There is and has been in the press, particularly in Queensland, a lot of speculation about whether or not Pauline Hanson will run for the Senate. Apparently her staff believe this is where the action is. If it is her intention to run for the Senate in order to gain some kind of balance of power in this chamber, I guess I will be at the epicentre of that struggle. Some say it would be my seat she would have to take in order to get here.

If, in any sense, I am under that kind of challenge, I certainly accept the fight. It is one I have been involved in for many, many years. I will be glad to continue to fight for the justice of this issue and for the kind of society that I want my children and grandchildren to grow up in. I do not expect to lose.

I suspect Pauline Hanson's push for the Senate would be very similar to the old `Joh for PM' campaign or, if you like, Bronwyn Bishop as leader of the Liberal Party—a phenomenon that is like a brief comet that wends its way across the political firmament and then expires. Believe me, I can assure you that Mr Pasquarelli is no Sir Robert Sparkes—and Queenslanders will understand that reference.

BREAK.PARA: There are greater issues in this debate than my political future and any challenge that Pauline Hanson might represent. I have a lifelong experience in those issues. I do not think people understand what can be unleashed when you make room in our society for extremists, and it actually happens. When you begin these kinds of debates, they never stay within the bounds of people who seem to think the debate is about freedom of speech or about the right of people to say what they think. The debate never stays within those boundaries. Once we have unleashed the debate, it is one in which we make room for extremists.

Let me read to you a letter. In 1984, as the Director for Social Responsibility for the Uniting Church in Queensland, I entered the debate on Asian immigration. You will remember it was a contribution partly made by our present Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Having entered that debate, I received this letter:
Revrend Woodley,
You are a traitor to the white race and Australia.
Your church is an organisation of fools, communists, and traitors. It teaches lies, not Christian truths.
We know where your live.
Think about that Revrend Woodley, we know where you and your family live.

If you continue to teach and preach mongrelisation with the inferior sub‐human breeds of articulate monkeys you will pay the price of treason and I am sure your knowledge of history makes you aware of the penalty for treason.
PS: If your memory fails you, look up what creative things were done with piano wire to the traitorous vermin who attempted to murder our Leader.

One could dismiss that as a lot of stupid nonsense, except that it was followed up for weeks by phone calls to my home that were in the same vein. Whenever my son or I answered the phone, the person who was calling would hang up. But when my wife or daughters answered it, then a message of that same kind was given to them. In the end it caused very great trauma, particularly for my 13-year-old daughter.

That is what happens when we open up this kind of debate and make space for extremists—and extremists certainly exist within our society. I do not want our society to go down that road. I have seen the effect that it has on people, particularly my own family. In the end, of course, we had to approach the police and other authorities in Queensland. Eventually, Telecom monitored our phone and we were able to stop it. But it did have a very serious effect on my family. We have to stare these attitudes down and declare openly, often and directly that they are unacceptable. We have to bear witness for tolerance, for honesty and for compassion.

This debate also interests me because often people are prepared to say that intolerance and discrimination will affect our trade in Asia whilst perhaps not being quite so ready to also say that they affect our Aboriginal people. I want to make sure, as is made sure in this particular motion, that we understand the effect this kind of debate has on all those people who are being affected by it.

Let me name some of the groups in Queensland that have been involved for many years in this kind of issue—groups like the League of Rights; many fascist groups with different names, such as the Australian National Association. These groups exist and have existed for a long time. Most of the time they have no effect on public debate. It is only when we open the box and make room for them that they begin to peddle their pernicious propaganda and affect the lives of people.

I hope that the Senate will indeed support the motion which has been moved. It is high time we did move such a motion. It should have been moved weeks ago. Perhaps I will not repeat what others have said about those leaders in our nation who perhaps could have done more. But finally, let me say: let us support this motion—and I hope, as Senator Harradine has said, that we support it unanimously.
