I would like to take a few moments in relaying to this chamber exactly where the National Museum is at. Many will be aware that, in its endless search for construction, the National Museum of Australia has been, once again, forced to jump through several hoops in its quest for a physical presence in the nation's capital, Canberra.

This particular report really highlights the very grand efforts of the staff of the National Museum in times when it must be very difficult for them to keep their morale as high as they obviously do in their work. Particularly, it is worth noting the work that has been done in taking the National Museum around Australia. One of its key result areas as noted in the report is access and making the collections of the National Museum accessible to people right around Australia.

Many senators will know that the bulk of the National Museum's collection is in a couple of warehouses in Canberra. Funding is provided on an annual basis to ensure the collection is maintained in adequate form for when the museum is ultimately constructed.

If honourable senators have not taken the opportunity yet to peruse the collection of the National Museum of Australia in the suburb of Mitchell, may I suggest that they do so and ask the very helpful staff to conduct them through the hallways, warehouses and storage areas of the National Museum of Australia.

So where is the National Museum going? It is still waiting, as it has for many years, for a decision by this parliament, or by the government of the day, to move to construct for it a permanent residence. The nature of that permanent residence has changed over the years with funding constraints, other pressures and contentious issues, such as the siting issue, impacting upon the museum. We will move slowly, but I am hopeful it will inevitably be towards the construction of the museum.

Its nature has also changed in that we are now talking about a hub of a collection that will be transported regularly around Australia. The innovative CD ROM collection the National Museum is putting together means that schools have the ability to access the collection through multimedia as well. The siting study that is being conducted at the moment is going through its own throes of uncertainty with new sites being introduced by the ACT government and others all the time.

At this point in noting this report, I would like to commend the work of the staff of the National Museum. I say to them, `Keep your spirits up. Keep the morale high.' I am hopeful that we will see the construction of a National Museum and am hopeful and ask that this government honour its commitment to construct the National Museum of Australia here in Canberra. It would be preferable at the Yarramundi site, but the siting study will no doubt provide some recommendation with regard to that.

Perhaps one day we will ultimately see what will prove to be one of the most exciting and innovative modern museums this country has ever seen. It will truly be a museum that not only we in Canberra, in the nation's capital, will be proud of but also every Australian will be proud of and hopefully visit.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There being no further documents for consideration, I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —At 4 o'clock this afternoon in Melbourne, Training Unionists for the Future was launched by the Hon. Clyde Cameron, who is a former Minister for Labour, a former Minister for Immigration and a former Minister for Science and Consumer Affairs in the Whitlam Labor government from 1972 to 1975. He was crucial to the setting up of the Trade Union Training Authority and, unfortunately, may I say, that initiative has now been frustrated. Nonetheless, there is a need for people who are members of unions and who are interested in seeing unionists and workers have an ability to cope in the workplace to be encouraged, and that is the purpose of the training unionists for the future scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: This scheme has been set up by the Victorian Trades Hall Council. The secretary of that council, Mr Leigh Hubbard, is the person who took over from Mr John Halfpenny and has done very good work since he came into office. This latest venture is certainly amongst the best that he has undertaken. The person who has done much of the work in getting the actual nuts and bolts together is Mr Greg McConville. I think it is an appropriate time to go through some of the work this organisation will perform.

It will get under way and start teaching people in January next year. It is interesting to see the topics this particular program will deal with. They will include learning in respect of workplace violence and workplace discrimination. The courses this body will run will include grievance and disciplinary procedures; communication strategies for unionists; media skills; compensation and rehabilitation; working together—organising and recruitment in the workplace; and, records management for union offices.

As I go through the list of subjects this institution will be dealing with, I can see that it is very comprehensive and very essential. A fee will be charged for the various courses, but it is an initiative that is funded completely by the trade union movement.

Education gained through this organisation's proposed initiative will enable workers' representatives to have the same abilities and conduct themselves in an equally skilled way as those with whom they will be negotiating—the employers and their representatives. It is a most essential initiative because, when the new industrial legislation we have been discussing today has been passed—as now seems inevitable, there being agreement between the coalition and the Democrats—there will be a crucial need for people to be able to handle themselves well in negotiations and for unions to be on equal terms with those they will be negotiating with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope they are not going to put some good barristers out of work.

—I think Senator O'Chee raises a very good point when he says that he hopes they will not put some very good barristers out of work. I do not think they will, Senator O'Chee. I think there will still be great scope for litigation when this legislation has been enacted. I think it will be very productive of litigation and there will be plenty of work for lawyers.

BREAK.PARA: This particular scheme is aimed at something different: it is aimed at enabling those who are actually in the workplace to be able to stand their ground, to be able to negotiate and to be able to understand the quite complicated negotiations they will have to go through. No doubt the various relevant unions themselves will help them in that, but there will be great need for people to be able to cope with the situation with which they will be faced.

I must confess that it has been exciting to see the Australian union movement—and particularly through that part of the movement in my own state connected with the Victorian Trades Hall Council and its secretary which I will always think of as the best part of the Australian union movement—move so rapidly into an area where it needs to go. It shows an ability to cope with problems as they start to become real and gather weight.

Perhaps it is only fair for me to say that a lot of the training and lessons that will be given will be based on the curriculum developed by the Trade Union Training Authority and by the Australian Committee for Training Curriculum. I think it only proper and right that I acknowledge the contribution that those two organisations have made to the programs put forward by the Training Unionists for the Future.

I notice that this opening took place in the executive room of the Victorian Trades Hall Council in Victoria Street, Carlton. That is a quite magnificent building, a building set up by workers that symbolises the dignity, confidence and `forward‐lookingness'—if I can use that expression—of workers in the last century and into this one. I invite Senator O'Chee, if he is down that way, to go and see the restoration work that has been done in that building which brings to life the history of the workers movement in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take you up on that offer.

—And I will make sure that you are given a guided tour, Senator O'Chee. It is, I think, a most symbolic gesture that Mr Cameron has launched this project in a building that shows the great history of the workers' movement in Victoria and in Australia. The launching of this project shows, as does that building, that the movement has a great future—particularly when you get people like Mr Hubbard and those who run the Victorian Trades Hall Council initiating projects like this and carrying them through with the `panache', which I think is the proper word, that they have on this occasion.

BREAK.PARA: I close by saying that I wish this new training initiative, Training Unionists for the Future, every success for the future, as I am sure everybody here would. I am sure that my wishes and those made by everybody else here will be fulfilled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity of the adjournment tonight to refer to the debate we had earlier today on what was meant to be a bipartisan motion on racial tolerance and equality, a motion that we do all support and a very clear and strong statement of the parliament's position. But I want to express my profound disappointment with the remarks made by Senator Bob Collins in the debate on this statement. I thought he made what can only be described as a distasteful, unhappy and unnecessary contribution to that debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion was drawn up in a bipartisan fashion by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) and the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) in the House of Representatives. It was aimed at achieving and expressing the support of the whole parliament for racial tolerance, equality, a non-discriminatory immigration policy and a reaffirmation of our position on reconciliation with Aboriginal Australians. Instead, we had Senator Bob Collins using the whole of his 20‐minute contribution to the debate not to advocate and uphold those worthy values but to attack the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of this country in an appalling, ugly and party political manner which I thought brought no credit to himself, the motion or this chamber.

It is a great pity that people like, in this case, Senator Bob Collins cannot help themselves. Any opportunity to exercise a party political position seems to be too attractive. In his attribution of very cynical and populist motives to the Prime Minister, I thought he was disgraceful in the way that he attacked him. It was nothing more than a personal attack on the character of the Prime Minister. Instead of taking advantage of the opportunity to make a statesmanlike statement on the important values that maintain this nation cohesively, he instead attacked the Prime Minister personally.

It seemed to be that Senator Collins was insisting, by his personal attacks on the Prime Minister, that the Prime Minister should be personally attacking Pauline Hanson. Of course, that is what the media seems to be demanding—that none of us should stand up without attacking Mrs Hanson personally. I have heard the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) do just that in radio interviews—attack the very character of Mrs Hanson.

I want to take advantage of this opportunity tonight to say that this is becoming an ugly feature of public policy debate in this country. I do not want to get party political, but it must be said that the former Prime Minister encouraged this particular feature of Australian debate—you do not talk about the merits of issues, the merits of proposals put forward by your opponents, but you personally attack them. You attack their character, you attack their motives, you attribute false motives to them in any way you can. Public debate in this country is far less civilised in that sense than it ought to be in terms of contributing to the sensible debate of public policy issues.

I have said that I am disappointed that Senator Collins, for whom I have said before I generally have some regard, has chosen to use this debate to personally attack the Prime Minister in this way rather than deal with the merits of the issues before us. In fact, it is part of the whole hysteria that has been whipped up by the media and others over this issue.

Tonight I want to refer briefly to what Mrs Hanson actually said, and what has, I guess, generated this debate and the motion today. The feature of her speech that has drawn most attention is this statement:

I and most Australians want our immigration policy radically reviewed and that of multiculturalism abolished. I believe we are in danger of being swamped by Asians. Between 1984 and 1995, 40 per cent of all migrants coming into this country were of Asian origin. They have their own culture and religion, form ghettos and do not assimilate.
Further, she said:
Immigration must be halted in the short term so that our dole queues are not added to by, in many cases, unskilled migrants not fluent in the English language.
That seems to be the guts of Mrs Hanson's speech that has caused the most anxiety and concern in the community, and those statements were obviously inaccurate, insensitive and uncalled for.

The point I want to make is that the Prime Minister has repeatedly and often stated, as a consequence of that speech, and subsequent to that speech, the government's position in relation to the issues raised by Mrs Hanson. He has dealt with the merits of the issues raised by her and the policy proposals put forward by her, and he has refrained from personal attacks on her. He has repeatedly stated the government's position on immigration: we are committed to an immigration program based on non-discrimination on the grounds of race. He has said that over and over again.

He has repeatedly stated this government's commitment to tolerance and equality regardless of race or the colour of one's skin. He has rejected her views on Aboriginal Australians. He has acknowledged their particular disadvantage and this government's commitment to dealing with that particular disadvantage. That is why I was disappointed with what Senator Collins said. He attributed false motives to the Prime Minister and then ignored the fact that the Prime Minister has dealt with the issues raised by Mrs Hanson in her speech. He did not, as I said, attack her personally, which seems to be what Senator Collins wants the Prime Minister to do.

I am not quite sure what Senator Collins wants the Prime Minister to do. Does he want the Prime Minister to order that Mrs Hanson be locked up or something? He has dealt with the issues raised by her in a matter of fact way. He could not have done more to repeat the government's position on the issues raised by her—this government is committed to non-discriminatory immigration policy. He has dealt with those issues raised by Mrs Hanson with great dignity, with great responsibility as the leader of this whole nation. I am sorry that Senator Collins in his contribution did nothing more than play party politics with a very important issue.

Both parties had worked together to draw up this statement and make it a bipartisan statement. Instead, Senator Collins used his opportunity to speak to just attack the Prime Minister for what he has allegedly not done or what his alleged motives are.

Senator Collins also seemed to attack the Prime Minister because he acknowledged that a lot of Australians agreed with Mrs Hanson. So Senator Collins seems to want the government to also deny reality as well as personally attack Mrs Hanson. The fact is, like it or not, many Australians do agree with many of the policies advocated by Mrs Hanson. That is a fact of life, whether we like it or not. Newspoll found that 71 per cent of Australians now want lower immigration. The Bulletin today says that 66 per cent want to stop immigration in the short term, and 51 per cent agree that Aborigines should get no special advantages. The Prime Minister has been attacked for simply acknowledging the reality that those are the opinions of a lot of Australians.

The paradox is that much of the state of public opinion in this country, which presumably Senator Collins does not like, can be attributed, in part, to the 13 years of Labor rule that we had in this country. The Labor Party's policies over that period—which were roundly attacked by one of its own ministers, Peter Walsh, in his very good book—were an out of control immigration program, a roller-coaster immigration program, massive unemployment and vicious government attacks on anyone who criticised any of the former government's policies.
I want to draw attention to a very good article by Professor Marilyn Lake, a professor of history at La Trobe University, who said:

That resentful workers, employed, self-employed or unemployed, erroneously blame Asian migrants, Aborigines and welfare recipients for their reduced circumstances simply highlights Labor's failure to provide alternative explanations, to come up with different ideas about how we came to be in the state that we're in and how we might move on.
Politics is about securing the electorate's identification as well as promoting ideas. Is the Labor Party capable of meeting the challenge?

I am afraid to say, as someone who has quite honestly respected Senator Collins in the past, that his contribution today, which I thought sullied what is otherwise a good bipartisan motion on these issues, represents the fact that the Labor Party apparently is not capable of meeting the challenge which Professor Lake has described in her very good article, which I think all Labor supporters and members ought to read because it sets out very clearly the great dilemma facing the Labor Party after its 13 years of government.

We all deplore the fact that so many Australians seem to agree with much of what Ms Hanson has said, but we must deal with that reality. It will serve this parliament no good if we pretend to ignore that reality or deal with this issue on the basis of personal attacks. Let us deal with the merits of the arguments and attack the arguments on their merits. I therefore conclude by saying I hope that Senator Collins's contributions will be constructive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Spoken, Senator Minchin, like a true political spin doctor, which of course is what you are. Interestingly enough, I actually came into the Senate this evening to talk about my own experiences and the Australian Labor Party's experiences in the Northern Territory with the firm DDB Needham.

SPEECH.PARA: You talk about personal attacks, Senator. Well, I suggest you listen in the next five minutes to what I have to say. We all know your associations with that company. Having sat here for a couple of minutes listening to your pious platitudes about how horrible it is to make personal attacks, knowing your association with DDB Needham and knowing the job they did on a Labor colleague of mine in the Northern Territory, which was one of the lowest political campaigns that I have ever seen in 20 years, I give all of your comments the weight they deserve—that is, nothing at all.

For the last two months this country's leader has adopted a two bob each way approach on this vital national issue—and Senator Minchin knows that those charges are fully made out. He was having two bob each way right up until yesterday—indeed today, as I said in debate earlier this evening. There were the subtle changes of wording in 24 hours. Yesterday he said what a dreadful thing it was that teachers were telling our school children that we had a racist and bigoted past. Today, with a single word addition, he totally changed the meaning of the script: he now says he rejects that we have had a `totally racist and bigoted past'.

That is the slippery slope that the Prime Minister has been tracking us down over the last two months. He has been doing it deliberately, Senator Minchin, and you know it—trying to appease both sides of the argument and to give comfort to both sides of the argument because his research is telling him that it is a popular view at the moment. It is a high price to pay, in my view, for a bit of populist domestic politics, because that is what it is.

With all the words that were uttered today and all the press analysis, this entire debate for me was summed up by Alan Moir's brilliant cartoon in today's Sydney Morning Herald. This is an award winner if there is any justice in cartoon awards. In a few square inches, in one picture, the Sydney Morning Herald cartoonist today summed up this debate better than all the words and all the speeches that have been uttered today.

The cartoon shows the Prime Minister with a speech in his hand, striking four different poses, and uttering the words: `I may not agree with what you say .. but I'll fight to the death for my right to be opportunistic.' That is it precisely: nailed to the mast—game, set and match. That one simple picture sums up the entire debate better than all the speeches that were delivered today and in the last two months.

I rise in the adjournment tonight to say a few words about the government's increasingly shrill attempts to claim that it did not fix the awarding of the $4 million in advertising contracts for the national gun buy‐back scheme to ensure that they were not awarded on merit, but awarded to companies that were owned by their mates. That is another case that has been fundamentally made out in these last few weeks by Senator Ray in Senate estimates committees.

Let me digress just a little. During a recent drive between Canberra and Melbourne, an acquaintance of mine made a diversion to a small town in the Murray Valley. He stopped in to see the lessee of one of the local hotels, a bloke called Terry Smith. In a previous life, Terry Smith was a prominent member of the Australian Labor Party in the Northern Territory. He was a quintessential territorian. He followed me, in fact, as leader of the party in the Northern Territory. He quit politics in 1991, a few months after he became the sole target, as leader of the Labor Party in the Northern Territory, of one of the most personally vicious advertising campaigns in Australian political history, which certainly had an effect on him personally and also on his family—his wife and children.

I have never seen a campaign like it. There is no getting away from—as tough as we all like to pretend we are—the extent to which he was personally attacked during at that campaign. Those responsible for that election campaign were the now Prime Minister's chief political adviser, Grahame Morris and the principals of DDB Needham, John King and Toby Ralph. An extraordinary interview with Toby Ralph in the Adelaide Advertiser, which I have quoted in this chamber before, said it all.

Ralph claimed, probably rightly, not only credit for the viciously personal campaign that denigrated Terry Smith—not the Labor Party, Senator Minchin, not policies, not issues of substance, but Terry Smith. It sent up his moustache, sent up his personal appearance and portrayed him as an effeminate person by calling him Terrence instead of Terry. It was a vicious campaign, and the only campaign they ran. Not only did Toby Ralph claim credit for it; he also claimed credit, probably rightly, for the advertising agency actually setting the date of the election itself rather than the Northern Territory government.
He told the newspaper, boasting about it, that the campaign, which was held in October 1991, was planned in mid‐September when:
John King, Toby Ralph and federal secretariat staffer Grahame Morris went to Darwin to recommend an election date and strategy.
After two days of intense debate, this group, that is, Morris, King and Ralph, decided on an election date for the Northern Territory of 27 October. The article continued:
"The first part of our negative strategy was a vicious attack on the Labor leader Terry Smith," Ralph says.

This is a quote from Ralph himself—a vicious attack on the Labor leader, Terry Smith. Senator Minchin, these are your friends—the ones you were just talking about that should not mount personal attacks on people. I quote Mr Ralph again:
"We wanted to position him as a knocker. This would make it difficult for him to attack us and force him to run an ineffective positive campaign—
Later in the same article, Ralph says:
We called him Terrence—not Terry—because it sounded more contrived and effeminate and very unterritorian . . .

This strategy was reinforced with saturation TV ads which featured an incredibly distorted head and shoulder shot of Terry Smith, now Terrence Smith, caught in a graphic similar to those red warning signals of `no smoking' signs.

In every single interview and in every single personal interaction that Terry Smith then had with government members—this is in the chamber of the parliament—members who had called him Terry for 20 years now called him Terrence. They called him Terrence for the whole time the campaign went on, even to his face in the chamber. It was absolutely personally sickening.

The campaign was totally alien to Australian political culture. It was the first time I had ever seen a classic American negative campaign in my life—I hope I never see another one. It was lifted straight from the United States of America.

When word of the article reached the territory—that is the boasting about them destroying Terry Smith as a person and choosing the date for the election—Ralph was immediately dubbed the `mouth from the south' in the Northern Territory. When you look at some of the things that he has said since, you would have to agree—for example, his comments after the recent federal election.

Ralph, one of the four members of the Liberal advertising team, was one of a number of people who spoke at a post-election symposium held by the Melbourne‐based Centre for Corporate Public Affairs on 15 April. One paragraph of his illusive contribution to this symposium is on page 321 of Michael Gordon's recent update on his book A True Believer. It says:

Andrew sort of got rid of the gentlemen farmers who had been hanging around the halls for a long time and put in a pretty professional bunch of dispassionate, almost mercenaries if you like, people you wouldn't like to meet down a dark alley at night . . .
They are your friends, Senator Minchin. I take great heart from the fact that this trio of political hatchet men are now in the gun themselves.

This is not the first time they have been embroiled in controversy over guns and advertising. There are those of us who recall the reaction to the Liberal Party's sniper TV ads during the 1993 federal election campaign showing Australians on TV screens in the gun sights—the crosshairs of a gun—of unemployment. Do you remember those ads, Senator Minchin?

The ad used the image of a sniper focusing on individuals caught in the crosshairs of a telescopic rifle waiting to be shot while a deep male voice asked who would be next. The ads caused an absolute storm, with the Coalition for Gun Control issuing press statements calling for them to be withdrawn because they encouraged gun violence, which they did. They were appalling advertisements. Their spokesperson, Rebecca Peters, said the ads were:
. . . a cynical exploitation of the tragic gun violence problem in this country. More than once a week an Australian is murdered with a gun.
The then ALP national secretary, Bob Hogg, said that he would rather give the game away than run ads like that.

What did the Liberal Party say? The then Deputy Director of the Liberal Party, Mr Grahame Morris, told the Sunday Age on 14 February of that year that the few complaints the party had received about the ads were `mild by political standards'. It is paradoxical that this same trio have been chosen by this government to put together an advertising campaign to encourage gun owners to comply with the buyback.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak again on the subject of education and on the statements the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, made today on the subject of literacy. Obviously, the minister has not felt the need to modify his inaccurate and his damaging comments made over the past week about—to put it in his own words—`the need for tough new accountability measures to improve literacy levels in our schools'.

SPEECH.PARA: On Radio National this morning, the author of the study on which the minister so liberally draws was asked how he felt when he picked up the paper and found headlines about all the year 9 students who could not read. He said:

Yes, I am surprised at the various interpretations that are placed on these things. That not achieving a mastery level of literacy becomes can't read and so on. I mean people are entitled to place their own interpretations on data but I think some of those interpretations weren't the ones we would have made.
Generous remarks I would say, given that we are talking about the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training.

Later on in the interview, the minister was asked why it was that he bothered to draw from this longitudinal study when we are right in the middle of the first ever detailed, expensive—$3 million—targeted national English literacy survey to be carried out in Australia. He was asked, `Why not just wait for those fresh results?' Why not, indeed.

I think we know the answer. It is because the minister chose to be selective and he did so because it suited his political purposes. Denigrate the education system, denigrate teachers and frighten parents into taking their children out of state schools so that they can pay fees for their children to be sent to private schools.

What was the minister's answer? It is a very long answer and I will not bore the Senate with the full text. I am happy to provide any senator with a full transcript if they are interested. We need to remember that this is a question about why the minister chose to use an inappropriate, incomplete study ranging over 20 years on the transition of young people from school to work rather than a study which is under way and which is designed to give the minister the data he needs.
The interviewer, Jane Figgins, also pointed out that the results of the study to be completed next year could not be sheeted home to schools or even to sectors of schools. The minister says:

What I was calling for was much more information to parents by individual schools about their performance. Parents are ringing schools and asking school principals long lists of questions about the school in order to make that choice—
of course, the minister does not make clear what choice he is referring to, but I can imagine that he means the choice between the public and the private sectors—
but the information is not available to them.
He says:

I was suggesting that that would be a very important kind of information that should be out there in the public and I'm not thinking of any simplistic measures in this regard, I think obviously some schools start with an advantage because a lot of their students come from highly literate households, on the other hand a number of schools are drawing students from families that don't have English as a first language or who suffer some other educational disadvantage. What parents want to know is not so much the starting point but whether the school is able to add value.

I get the feeling here that the minister is confusing our children with products and industry when he talks about adding value. However, Jane Figgins on Radio National again tries to get the minister to address the question of what the government wants to achieve. She says:

I would have thought that being consistent with what you are saying is that you would really look for some absolute standards and, no matter what background a child came from, it would be unacceptable if they did not reach those standards.
The minister replied:

Well, I think as a community of course we aim to do that, we aim to have every child literate and we will be seeking out of the National English Literacy Survey to set national standards for literacy for years 3 and 5. We need to make sure that teachers have available to them a way of assessing their entrance into grade one so that they can identify those students who have already achieved a good level of literacy—
a good level of literacy, I ask the minister, in grade 1?—
and those who are going to need particular attention. We will need to look at the curriculum and say, `Does it allow sufficient time for students to gain literacy skills?'
I will not repeat the remarks which I made here yesterday about the absurdity of such simplistic approaches to solving problems associated with literacy.

The minister told us today that there is research which suggests that there are many students who simply do not find the time in the curriculum, and that many teachers are frustrated at the moment because of the amount that they are being asked to do. I would like to suggest to the minister that one way of dealing with this would be to see that class sizes are reduced so that teachers can spend more time with individual students. As a teacher, I can assure the minister that there is a far better chance of being able to deal with literacy in all its facets with a class of 20 children than one with 25 or 30. I remind the minister that in my home state of Victoria the state government has actually increased class sizes and reduced support services for teachers. The minister also needs to be reminded that teachers often cope with composite classes of two and three levels in which the literacy achievements of students are highly varied.

Another matter I want to address is the question of broadbanding and literacy. As the Senate will be aware, the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 1996, which is before the Senate committee, includes a proposal by the government to do what is called broadbanding for government programs. This involves reducing the number of programs of targeted assistance from more than 40 to just five. One of these is literacy. These 40‐odd targeted assistance programs did just that: they targeted assistance to those students who were most disadvantaged, educationally and socially. They acknowledged the direct relationship between social and economic circumstances and education outcomes. They were a genuine attempt to introduce some across‐the‐board equity into primary and secondary education.

Literacy may well be one of the five priority areas under the government's broadbanding proposals, but it is not going to deliver real improvements in literacy in the absence of a solid commitment to equity and to reducing disadvantage. You will notice that Minister Kemp never mentions that word `equity'. Perhaps it has become a dirty word. In any case, it seems to have disappeared in relation to education. The government, it seems to me, is saying that if it lets parents know the truth, if the government develops a policy and if we get literacy programs in place, then it is all just a matter of students knuckling down and getting on with it and—hey, presto!—every student will magically be able to master literacy or learn to read; we are not sure which the minister is aiming for.

Disregard the circumstances of those students' lives, disregard their cultural backgrounds, disregard the standard of equipment, the class sizes, and all those other factors which impact on a child's ability to achieve standards of literacy. We all know that this is simplistic arrogant nonsense. An education system that fails to acknowledge the connection between socioeconomic status and school outcomes is a system which will fail many, if not all, of those disadvantaged students.

Take the STAR program, for example. That program assisted schools to identify students most at risk of not completing secondary school, and it encouraged their participation through a range of school based projects. Because of the sorts of students involved in these programs, many STAR projects actually focused on basic literacy and numeracy skills in combination with addressing the health, housing and other needs of students. In short, STAR did not just try to get students reading and writing in isolation and it did not simply give them more English classes instead of sport; it took those problems in context and it recognised that poor literacy and numeracy skills were a consequence—and an exacerbation, I might say—of those other social and economic problems. I remind the Senate that STAR has, of course, been abolished by this government.
In the words of Joan Brown, the Director of the Australian Centre for Equity Through Education:

Nowhere in the government's new programs is there recognition that students are coming to school with complex social and health problems that schools and teachers are not trained or resourced to deal with.

I urge the minister, for the sake of Australian children, to start to listen to what educators are saying instead of alarming people with his predictably simplistic phrases about information not being available to parents, about competition and choice—whatever those words mean—in the context of an education system serving 70 per cent of Australian children, and in the context of the many students who, in some way, are less advantaged than others.

By failing to explicitly address equity issues, the minister's broadbanding effectively ends any federal government commitment to nationally target those students and communities most in need. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this debate—
—Haven't we heard enough of this bloke today?

—No, you haven't, Senator Panizza. You have not heard enough of me today. I rise to speak on two issues, one of which was raised in question time today. It relates to the issue of the fit‐out of a senator's office. I just want to briefly say that—

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the appointment of Mr Brendan Smyth as an adviser to the Minister:
(1) Was the position advertised; if so, in what publications; if not, why not.
(2) What are the levels of salary and allowance paid to Mr Smyth.
Are these less than, greater than or equivalent to his previous salary and allowances as the Federal Member for Canberra.
(4) Is Mr Smyth a permanent public servant.
(5) What are his precise roles and duties.
(6)(a) What amount of travel is involved in his position; (b) where is this travel to; and (c) what is its purpose.
(7) How much has this travel cost so far and how much is it expected to cost to the end of the 1996‐97 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr Smyth responded to the general advertisement placed in the major daily newspapers on 9 March 1996. No positions in the Minister's office were specifically advertised. All positions were filled either from people who responded to general advertisements or who were directly approached.
(2) $60,147 per annum plus Ministerial Staff Allowance of $11,200 per annum.
(3) Less than.
(5) Ministerial Adviser Duties as instructed by the Minister including departmental and community liaison.
(6)(a) As required.
(b) Dates and destinations:‐

31 May 1996—Wollongong; 5‐6 June 1996—Orange; 12‐14 June 1996—Melbourne & Hobart; 17‐21 June 1996—Adelaide and Perth; 2‐5 July 1996—Sydney; 9‐12 July 1996—Townsville and Brisbane; 25‐26 July 1996—Newcastle & Sydney; 29‐31 July 1996—Shepparton and Bendigo; 5‐8 August 1996—Darwin
(c) Liaison with departmental officers and community groups.
(7) The cost of Mr Smyth's travel from 13 May 1996 to 20 August 1996 totalled $9,578.88 for airfares, travelling allowance and car transport. Further travel will be as his duties require.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology upon notice on 1 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funds will be allocated for the continued research and investigation into managing feral species using fertility control methods.
(2) Should Rabbit Calicivirus Disease (RCD) be officially released and will this in any way affect the research currently being undertaken in rabbit fertility control.
(3) What percentage of Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO's) funds are spent on research involving invasive procedures on animals.
(4) What percentage of funds are spent on the investigation and development of alternatives to animal use in research projects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) $2.8 million has been allocated by CSIRO for research into fertility control of feral species.

(2) Rabbit Calicivirus Disease (RCD) has already been declared a biological control agent. RCD has no direct financial implications on research into fertility control. Existence of rabbit calicivirus disease in the field (escaped and released) will affect the dynamics of rabbit populations and can be expected to alter the dynamics of any immunosterilising agent or organism. These effects will be taken into account, in decisions on the proposed mode, design and strategic use of any immunosterilising agent or organism.

(3) CSIRO is committed to the conduct of research for the benefit of all Australians. Its animal based research includes research in support of the domesticated livestock industries, research to provide a basis for the management of native and introduced fauna, research directed at a better understanding of human nutritional and nutritionally‐related pharmacological needs and research for the enhancement of non‐human animal well‐being.

If "invasive" is deemed to encompass surgical intervention with non‐human animals, then CSIRO's research or research‐related activities range from routine livestock husbandry practices, such as castration, dehorning, tail‐docking and so on to those involving the placement of indwelling catheters in physiological studies.
CSIRO does not separately account for the funding of its research involving invasive procedures.

(4) Wherever possible, CSIRO uses alternatives to the use of non‐human animals for the conduct of research. It does so for animal welfare reasons and for reasons of cost; alternative procedures, when available, are usually cheaper.

CSIRO's Animal Experimentation Committees (AECs) are set up under the terms of the Australian Code of Practice for the Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes, a code to which CSIRO is a signatory. AECs approve and oversee the conduct of the Organisation's animal‐based research and their approval process requires, at the outset, demonstration that alternatives are not available or suitable for the purposes of the planned research.

CSIRO's research does not consciously seek to develop alternatives to animal use but, where the potential for these arises, they are developed. European Community and United States laboratories are conducting significant research into the development of alternatives to the routine testing of cosmetics, human pharmacological agents, household products and addictive substances. CSIRO does not undertake such testing, nor is it involved in undergraduate teaching of surgical techniques or vehicle accident studies involving non‐human animals.
CSIRO does not separately account for the funding of its work concerned with alternatives to animal‐based research.
